   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Canada</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Canada_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Canada (disambiguation)">Canada (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in North America
      </div> 
      <p> <span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Canada&amp;params=60_N_110_W_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">60°N</span> <span class="longitude">110°W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">60°N 110°W</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">60; -110</span></span></span></a></span></span></span> </p>

             <a href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg" class="image" title="Coat of arms of Canada"><img alt="At the top there is a rendition of St. Edward's Crown, with the crest of a crowned gold lion standing on a twisted wreath of red and white silk and holding a maple leaf in its right paw underneath. The lion is standing on top of a helm, which is above the escutcheon, ribbon, motto and compartment. There is a supporter of either side of the escutcheon and ribbon; an English lion on the left and a Scottish unicorn on the right." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4f/Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg/85px-Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg.png" decoding="async" width="85" height="114" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4f/Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg/128px-Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4f/Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg/170px-Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="149" data-file-height="200"></a>

        <tr>
         <th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini</a>&nbsp;<span style="font-weight:normal;">(2017)</span></th>
         <td><img alt="Negative increase" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Increase_Negative.svg/11px-Increase_Negative.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Negative increase" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Increase_Negative.svg/17px-Increase_Negative.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Increase_Negative.svg/22px-Increase_Negative.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300">&nbsp;31.0<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup><br><span style="white-space:nowrap;"><span style="color:orange">medium</span></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">HDI</a>&nbsp;<span style="font-weight:normal;">(2019)</span></th>
         <td><img alt="Increase" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Increase" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300">&nbsp;0.929<sup id="cite_ref-UNHDR_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNHDR-10">[10]</a></sup><br><span style="white-space:nowrap;"><span style="color:darkgreen">very high</span></span>&nbsp;·&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">16th</a></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th scope="row">Currency</th>
         <td><a href="/wiki/Canadian_dollar" title="Canadian dollar">Canadian dollar</a> ($) (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">CAD</a>)</td>
        </tr>
        <tr class="mergedtoprow">
         <th scope="row">Time zone</th>
         <td><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>−3.5 to −8</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr class="mergedbottomrow">
         <th scope="row">
          <div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">
           •&nbsp;Summer&nbsp;(<a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time" title="Daylight saving time">DST</a>)
          </div></th>
         <td><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>−2.5 to −7</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th scope="row">Date format</th>
         <td><abbr title="year">yyyy</abbr>-<abbr title="month">mm</abbr>-<abbr title="day">dd</abbr>&nbsp;(<a href="/wiki/Anno_Domini" title="Anno Domini">AD</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Left-_and_right-hand_traffic" title="Left- and right-hand traffic">Driving side</a></th>
         <td>right</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Canada" title="Telephone numbers in Canada">Calling code</a></th>
         <td><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Canada" title="Telephone numbers in Canada">+1</a></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th>
         <td><a href="/wiki/.ca" title=".ca">.ca</a></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Canada</b> is a country in the northern part of <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>. Its <a href="/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada" title="Provinces and territories of Canada">ten provinces and three territories</a> extend from the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific</a> and northward into the <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Ocean" title="Arctic Ocean">Arctic Ocean</a>, covering 9.98&nbsp;million square kilometres (3.85&nbsp;million square miles), making it the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">second-largest country by total area</a>. Its southern and western <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_border" title="Canada–United States border">border with the United States</a>, stretching 8,891 kilometres (5,525&nbsp;mi), is the world's longest bi-national land border. Canada's capital is <a href="/wiki/Ottawa" title="Ottawa">Ottawa</a>, and its three <a href="/wiki/List_of_census_metropolitan_areas_and_agglomerations_in_Canada" title="List of census metropolitan areas and agglomerations in Canada">largest metropolitan areas</a> are <a href="/wiki/Toronto" title="Toronto">Toronto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Montreal" title="Montreal">Montreal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vancouver" title="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>. </p>
      <p>Various <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Canada" title="Indigenous peoples in Canada">Indigenous peoples inhabited what is now Canada</a> for thousands of years before European colonization. Beginning in the 16th century, <a href="/wiki/British_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="British colonization of the Americas">British</a> and <a href="/wiki/French_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="French colonization of the Americas">French</a> expeditions explored and later settled along the Atlantic coast. As a consequence of <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Canada" title="Military history of Canada">various armed conflicts</a>, France ceded nearly all of <a href="/wiki/New_France" title="New France">its colonies in North America</a> in 1763. In 1867, with the union of three <a href="/wiki/British_North_America" title="British North America">British North American</a> colonies through <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Confederation" title="Canadian Confederation">Confederation</a>, Canada was formed as a <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federal</a> <a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">dominion</a> of four provinces. This began an <a href="/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_Canada" title="Territorial evolution of Canada">accretion of provinces and territories</a> and a process of increasing autonomy from the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>. This widening autonomy was highlighted by the <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_1931" title="Statute of Westminster 1931">Statute of Westminster 1931</a> and culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Canada_Act_1982" title="Canada Act 1982">Canada Act 1982</a>, which severed the vestiges of legal dependence on the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">British Parliament</a>. </p>
      <p>Canada is a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" class="mw-redirect" title="Parliamentary democracy">parliamentary democracy</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster tradition</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Canada" title="Monarchy of Canada">monarch</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Canada" title="Prime Minister of Canada">prime minister</a> who serves as the chair of the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Canada" title="Cabinet of Canada">Cabinet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Canada" title="Government of Canada">head of government</a>. The country is a <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realm" title="Commonwealth realm">Commonwealth realm</a> and is <a href="/wiki/Official_bilingualism_in_Canada" title="Official bilingualism in Canada">officially bilingual</a> at the federal level. It <a href="/wiki/International_rankings_of_Canada" title="International rankings of Canada">ranks among the highest</a> in international measurements of government transparency, civil liberties, quality of life, <a href="/wiki/Economic_freedom" title="Economic freedom">economic freedom</a>, and education. It is one of the world's most ethnically diverse and <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism_in_Canada" title="Multiculturalism in Canada">multicultural</a> nations, the product of <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Canada" title="Immigration to Canada">large-scale immigration</a> from many other countries. Canada's <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Canada–United States relations">long and complex relationship with the United States</a> has had a significant impact on <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Canada" title="Economy of Canada">its economy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Canada" title="Culture of Canada">culture</a>. </p>
      <p>As a highly <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a>, Canada has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">seventeenth-highest nominal per-capita income globally</a> as well as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">thirteenth-highest</a> ranking in the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>. Its advanced economy is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">tenth-largest in the world</a>, relying chiefly upon its abundant natural resources and well-developed international trade networks. Canada is part of several major international and intergovernmental institutions or groupings including the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_Seven" title="Group of Seven">G7</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_Ten_(economics)" title="Group of Ten (economics)">Group of Ten</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement" title="United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement">United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">Organisation internationale de la Francophonie</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> forum. </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Canada" title="Name of Canada">Name of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <p>While a variety of theories have been postulated for the etymological origins of <i>Canada</i>, the name is now accepted as coming from the <a href="/wiki/St._Lawrence_Iroquoians" title="St. Lawrence Iroquoians">St. Lawrence Iroquoian</a> word <i lang="lre" title="Laurentian-language text">kanata</i>, meaning "village" or "settlement".<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> In 1535, Indigenous inhabitants of the present-day <a href="/wiki/Quebec_City" title="Quebec City">Quebec City</a> region used the word to direct French explorer <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Cartier" title="Jacques Cartier">Jacques Cartier</a> to the village of <a href="/wiki/Stadacona" title="Stadacona">Stadacona</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rayburn2001_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rayburn2001-13">[13]</a></sup> Cartier later used the word <i>Canada</i> to refer not only to that particular village but to the entire area subject to <a href="/wiki/Donnacona" title="Donnacona">Donnacona</a> (the chief at Stadacona);<sup id="cite_ref-Rayburn2001_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rayburn2001-13">[13]</a></sup> by 1545, European books and maps had begun referring to this small region along the <a href="/wiki/Saint_Lawrence_River" title="Saint Lawrence River">Saint Lawrence River</a> as <i>Canada</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rayburn2001_13-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rayburn2001-13">[13]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>From the 16th to the early 18th century "<a href="/wiki/Canada_(New_France)" title="Canada (New France)">Canada</a>" referred to the part of <a href="/wiki/New_France" title="New France">New France</a> that lay along the Saint Lawrence River.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> In 1791, the area became two British colonies called <a href="/wiki/Upper_Canada" title="Upper Canada">Upper Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lower_Canada" title="Lower Canada">Lower Canada</a> collectively named <a href="/wiki/The_Canadas" title="The Canadas">the Canadas</a>; until their union as the British <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Canada" title="Province of Canada">Province of Canada</a> in 1841.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> Upon Confederation in 1867, <i>Canada</i> was adopted as the legal name for the new country at the <a href="/wiki/London_Conference_of_1866" title="London Conference of 1866">London Conference</a>, and the word <i><a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">Dominion</a></i> was conferred as the country's title.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> By the 1950s, the term Dominion of Canada was no longer used by the United Kingdom, which considered Canada a "Realm of the Commonwealth".<sup id="cite_ref-Morra2016_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morra2016-17">[17]</a></sup> The government of <a href="/wiki/Louis_St._Laurent" title="Louis St. Laurent">Louis St. Laurent</a> ended the practice of using <i>Dominion</i> in the statutes of Canada in 1951.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1982, the passage of the Canada Act, bringing the Constitution of Canada fully under Canadian control, referred only to <i>Canada</i>, while later that year the name of the national holiday was <a href="/wiki/Canada_Day#History" title="Canada Day">changed from Dominion Day to Canada Day</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-buckner_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-buckner-20">[20]</a></sup> The term <i>Dominion</i> was used to distinguish the federal government from the provinces, though after the <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Canada_during_World_War_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Military history of Canada during World War II">Second World War</a> the term <i>federal</i> had replaced <i>dominion</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Canada" title="History of Canada">History of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Canadian_history" title="Timeline of Canadian history">Timeline of Canadian history</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_years_in_Canada" title="List of years in Canada">List of years in Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Historiography_of_Canada" title="Historiography of Canada">Historiography of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Indigenous_peoples">Indigenous peoples</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Langs_N.Amer.svg" class="image"><img alt="Colour-coded map of North America showing the distribution of North American language families north of Mexico" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Langs_N.Amer.svg/310px-Langs_N.Amer.svg.png" decoding="async" width="310" height="281" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Langs_N.Amer.svg/465px-Langs_N.Amer.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Langs_N.Amer.svg/620px-Langs_N.Amer.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="619" data-file-height="562"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Langs_N.Amer.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Indigenous_languages_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous languages of the Americas">Linguistic areas of North American Indigenous peoples</a> at the time of European contact
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Canada" title="Indigenous peoples in Canada">Indigenous peoples in present-day Canada</a> include the <a href="/wiki/First_Nations" title="First Nations">First Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Inuit" title="Inuit">Inuit</a>, and <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9tis_people_(Canada)" class="mw-redirect" title="Métis people (Canada)">Métis</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-GraberKuprecht2012_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GraberKuprecht2012-22">[22]</a></sup> the last being a <a href="/wiki/Mixed-blood" title="Mixed-blood">mixed-blood</a> people who originated in the mid-17th century when First Nations people married European settlers and subsequently developed their own identity.<sup id="cite_ref-GraberKuprecht2012_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GraberKuprecht2012-22">[22]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_migration_and_settlement_of_the_Americas_from_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="Prehistoric migration and settlement of the Americas from Asia">first inhabitants of North America</a> are generally hypothesized to have migrated from <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a> by way of the <a href="/wiki/Beringia" title="Beringia">Bering land bridge</a> and arrived at least 14,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FaganDurrani2016_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FaganDurrani2016-24">[24]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Paleo-Indian" class="mw-redirect" title="Paleo-Indian">Paleo-Indian</a> archeological sites at <a href="/wiki/Old_Crow_Flats" title="Old Crow Flats">Old Crow Flats</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bluefish_Caves" title="Bluefish Caves">Bluefish Caves</a> are two of the oldest sites of human habitation in Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-Rawat2012_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rawat2012-25">[25]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Technological_and_industrial_history_of_Canada#The_Stone_Age:_Fire_(14,000_BC_–_AD_1600)" title="Technological and industrial history of Canada">characteristics of Indigenous societies</a> included permanent settlements, agriculture, complex societal hierarchies, and trading networks.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> Some of these cultures had collapsed by the time European explorers arrived in the late 15th and early 16th centuries and have only been discovered through archeological investigations.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Population_history_of_indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Population history of indigenous peoples of the Americas">Indigenous population</a> at the time of the first European settlements is estimated to have been between 200,000<sup id="cite_ref-dying_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dying-29">[29]</a></sup> and two million,<sup id="cite_ref-Steckel_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Steckel-30">[30]</a></sup> with a figure of 500,000 accepted by Canada's <a href="/wiki/Royal_Commission_on_Aboriginal_Peoples" title="Royal Commission on Aboriginal Peoples">Royal Commission on Aboriginal Peoples</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> As a consequence of European colonization, the Indigenous population declined by forty to eighty percent, and several First Nations, such as the <a href="/wiki/Beothuk" title="Beothuk">Beothuk</a>, disappeared.<sup id="cite_ref-Marshall1998_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marshall1998-32">[32]</a></sup> The decline is attributed to several causes, including the <a href="/wiki/Columbian_Exchange" class="mw-redirect" title="Columbian Exchange">transfer of European diseases</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Influenza" title="Influenza">influenza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Measles" title="Measles">measles</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a> to which they had no natural immunity,<sup id="cite_ref-dying_29-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dying-29">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> conflicts over the fur trade, conflicts with the colonial authorities and settlers, and the loss of Indigenous lands to settlers and the subsequent collapse of several nations' self-sufficiency.<sup id="cite_ref-LaidlawLester2015_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LaidlawLester2015-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Although not without conflict, <a href="/wiki/Euro-Canadian" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro-Canadian">European Canadians</a>' early interactions with First Nations and Inuit populations were relatively peaceful.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> First Nations and Métis peoples played a critical part in the development of <a href="/wiki/Former_colonies_and_territories_in_Canada" title="Former colonies and territories in Canada">European colonies in Canada</a>, particularly for their role in assisting European <a href="/wiki/Coureur_des_bois" title="Coureur des bois">coureur des bois</a> and <a href="/wiki/Voyageurs" title="Voyageurs">voyageurs</a> in the exploration of the continent during the <a href="/wiki/North_American_fur_trade" title="North American fur trade">North American fur trade</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Miller2009j_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Miller2009j-37">[37]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/The_Canadian_Crown_and_Aboriginal_peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="The Canadian Crown and Aboriginal peoples">The Crown and Indigenous peoples</a> began <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_colonization_of_North_America" class="mw-redirect" title="Timeline of colonization of North America">interactions</a> during the European colonization period, though the Inuit, in general, had more limited interaction with European settlers.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> However, from the late 18th century, European Canadians encouraged Indigenous peoples to assimilate into their own culture.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> These attempts reached a climax in the late 19th and early 20th centuries with <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Indian_residential_school_system" title="Canadian Indian residential school system">forced integration</a> and <a href="/wiki/High_Arctic_relocation" title="High Arctic relocation">relocations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> A period of redress is underway, which started with the appointment of the <a href="/wiki/Truth_and_Reconciliation_Commission_of_Canada" title="Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada">Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Canada" title="Government of Canada">Government of Canada</a> in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_colonization">European colonization</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg/310px-Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="310" height="221" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg/465px-Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg/620px-Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1530" data-file-height="1090"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of territorial claims in <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a> by 1750, before the <a href="/wiki/French_and_Indian_War" title="French and Indian War">French and Indian War</a>, which was part of the greater worldwide conflict known as the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a> (1756 to 1763). Possessions of Britain (pink), <a href="/wiki/New_France" title="New France">New France</a> (blue), and Spain (orange, <i>California, Pacific Northwest, and Great Basin not indicated</i>)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>It is believed that the first European to explore the east coast of Canada was <a href="/wiki/Vikings" title="Vikings">Norse</a> explorer <a href="/wiki/Leif_Erikson" title="Leif Erikson">Leif Erikson</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-JohansenPritzker2007p727_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JohansenPritzker2007p727-43">[43]</a></sup> In approximately 1000 AD, the Norse built a small encampment that only lasted a few years at <a href="/wiki/L%27Anse_aux_Meadows" title="L'Anse aux Meadows">L'Anse aux Meadows</a> on the northern tip of <a href="/wiki/Newfoundland" class="mw-redirect" title="Newfoundland">Newfoundland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CordellLightfoot2008_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CordellLightfoot2008-44">[44]</a></sup> No further European exploration occurred until 1497, when Italian seafarer <a href="/wiki/John_Cabot" title="John Cabot">John Cabot</a> explored and claimed Canada's <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Canada" title="Atlantic Canada">Atlantic coast</a> in the name of King <a href="/wiki/Henry_VII_of_England" title="Henry VII of England">Henry VII of England</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BlakeKeshen2017p19_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BlakeKeshen2017p19-45">[45]</a></sup> In 1534, French explorer Jacques Cartier explored the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Saint_Lawrence" title="Gulf of Saint Lawrence">Gulf of Saint Lawrence</a> where, on July 24, he planted a 10-metre (33&nbsp;ft) cross bearing the words "Long Live the King of France" and took possession of the territory New France in the name of <a href="/wiki/Francis_I_of_France" title="Francis I of France">King Francis I</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> The early 16th century saw European mariners with navigational techniques pioneered by the <a href="/wiki/Basque_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Basque people">Basque</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_discoveries" title="Portuguese discoveries">Portuguese</a> establish seasonal whaling and fishing outposts along the Atlantic coast.<sup id="cite_ref-Kerr1987n_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kerr1987n-47">[47]</a></sup> In general, early settlements during <a href="/wiki/The_Age_of_Discovery" class="mw-redirect" title="The Age of Discovery">the Age of Discovery</a> appear to have been <a href="/wiki/Population_of_Canada#Ephemeral_European_settlements" title="Population of Canada">short-lived</a> due to a combination of the harsh climate, problems with navigating trade routes and competing outputs in Scandinavia.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Wynn2007_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wynn2007-49">[49]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1583, Sir <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Gilbert" title="Humphrey Gilbert">Humphrey Gilbert</a>, by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_prerogative" title="Royal prerogative">royal prerogative</a> of <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_I_of_England" class="mw-redirect" title="Elizabeth I of England">Queen Elizabeth I</a>, founded <a href="/wiki/St._John%27s,_Newfoundland_and_Labrador" title="St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador">St. John's, Newfoundland</a>, as the first North American <a href="/wiki/English_overseas_possessions" title="English overseas possessions">English seasonal camp</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> In 1600, the French established their first seasonal trading post at <a href="/wiki/Tadoussac" title="Tadoussac">Tadoussac</a> along the Saint Lawrence.<sup id="cite_ref-CordellLightfoot2008_44-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CordellLightfoot2008-44">[44]</a></sup> French explorer <a href="/wiki/Samuel_de_Champlain" title="Samuel de Champlain">Samuel de Champlain</a> arrived in 1603 and established the first permanent year-round European settlements at <a href="/wiki/Port_Royal,_Annapolis_County,_Nova_Scotia" title="Port Royal, Annapolis County, Nova Scotia">Port Royal</a> (in 1605) and Quebec City (in 1608).<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> Among the <a href="/wiki/French_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="French colonization of the Americas">colonists</a> of New France, <i><a href="/wiki/French_Canadian" class="mw-redirect" title="French Canadian">Canadiens</a></i> extensively settled the Saint Lawrence River valley and <a href="/wiki/Acadians" title="Acadians">Acadians</a> settled the present-day <a href="/wiki/The_Maritimes" title="The Maritimes">Maritimes</a>, while fur traders and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_the_Age_of_Discovery" title="Catholic Church and the Age of Discovery">Catholic missionaries</a> explored the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Bay" title="Hudson Bay">Hudson Bay</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Mississippi_watershed" class="mw-redirect" title="Mississippi watershed">Mississippi watershed</a> to <a href="/wiki/Louisiana_(New_France)" title="Louisiana (New France)">Louisiana</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Beaver_Wars" title="Beaver Wars">Beaver Wars</a> broke out in the mid-17th century over control of the North American fur trade.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The English established additional settlements in <a href="/wiki/Newfoundland_(island)" title="Newfoundland (island)">Newfoundland</a>, beginning in 1610 and the <a href="/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies" title="Thirteen Colonies">Thirteen Colonies</a> to the south were founded soon after.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hornsby_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hornsby-55">[55]</a></sup> A series of <a href="/wiki/French_and_Indian_Wars" title="French and Indian Wars">four wars</a> erupted in colonial North America between 1689 and 1763; the later wars of the period constituted the North American theatre of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> Mainland <a href="/wiki/Nova_Scotia" title="Nova Scotia">Nova Scotia</a> came under British rule with the 1713 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Utrecht" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Utrecht">Treaty of Utrecht</a>, and Canada and most of New France came under British rule in 1763 after the Seven Years' War.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="British_North_America">British North America</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Benjamin_West_005.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Painting of General Wolfe dying in front of the British flag while attended by officers and native allies" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Benjamin_West_005.jpg/220px-Benjamin_West_005.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Benjamin_West_005.jpg/330px-Benjamin_West_005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Benjamin_West_005.jpg/440px-Benjamin_West_005.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="2304"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Benjamin_West_005.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Benjamin_West" title="Benjamin West">Benjamin West</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Death_of_General_Wolfe" title="The Death of General Wolfe">The Death of General Wolfe</a></i> (1771) dramatizes <a href="/wiki/James_Wolfe" title="James Wolfe">James Wolfe</a>'s death during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Plains_of_Abraham" title="Battle of the Plains of Abraham">Battle of the Plains of Abraham</a> at <a href="/wiki/Quebec_City" title="Quebec City">Quebec</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Proclamation_of_1763" title="Royal Proclamation of 1763">Royal Proclamation of 1763</a> established First Nation treaty rights, created the <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Quebec_(1763%E2%80%931791)" title="Province of Quebec (1763–1791)">Province of Quebec</a> out of New France, and annexed <a href="/wiki/Cape_Breton_Island" title="Cape Breton Island">Cape Breton Island</a> to Nova Scotia.<sup id="cite_ref-buckner_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-buckner-20">[20]</a></sup> St. John's Island (now <a href="/wiki/Prince_Edward_Island" title="Prince Edward Island">Prince Edward Island</a>) became a separate colony in 1769.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> To avert conflict in Quebec, the British Parliament passed the <a href="/wiki/Quebec_Act" title="Quebec Act">Quebec Act 1774</a>, expanding Quebec's territory to the Great Lakes and <a href="/wiki/Ohio_River" title="Ohio River">Ohio Valley</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Hopkins1898_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hopkins1898-59">[59]</a></sup> More importantly, the <i>Quebec Act</i> afforded Quebec special autonomy and rights of self-administration at a time when the Thirteen Colonies were increasingly agitating against British rule.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> It re-established the <a href="/wiki/French_language_in_Canada" title="French language in Canada">French language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholicism_in_Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholicism in Canada">Catholic faith</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Law_of_France" title="Law of France">French civil law</a> there, staving off the growth of an independence movement in contrast to the Thirteen Colonies.<sup id="cite_ref-StuartSavage2011_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-StuartSavage2011-61">[61]</a></sup> The Proclamation and the Quebec Act in turn angered many residents of the Thirteen Colonies, further fuelling anti-British sentiment in the years prior to the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-buckner_20-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-buckner-20">[20]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the successful American War of Independence, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1783)" title="Treaty of Paris (1783)">1783 Treaty of Paris</a> recognized the independence of the newly formed United States and set the terms of peace, ceding <a href="/wiki/British_North_America" title="British North America">British North American</a> territories south of the Great Lakes and east of the Mississippi River to the new country.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> The American war of independence also caused a large out-migration of <a href="/wiki/Loyalists" class="mw-redirect" title="Loyalists">Loyalists</a>, the settlers who had fought against American independence. Many moved to Canada, particularly <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Canada" title="Atlantic Canada">Atlantic Canada</a>, where their arrival changed the demographic distribution of the existing territories. <a href="/wiki/New_Brunswick" title="New Brunswick">New Brunswick</a> was in turn split from Nova Scotia as part of a reorganization of Loyalist settlements in the Maritimes which led to the incorporation of <a href="/wiki/Saint_John,_New_Brunswick" title="Saint John, New Brunswick">Saint John, New Brunswick</a> to become Canada's first city.<sup id="cite_ref-Newman2016_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Newman2016-63">[63]</a></sup> To accommodate the influx of English-speaking Loyalists in Central Canada, the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Act_1791" title="Constitutional Act 1791"><i>Constitutional Act</i></a> of 1791 divided the province of Canada into French-speaking Lower Canada (later <a href="/wiki/Quebec#Canadian_Confederation" title="Quebec">Quebec</a>) and English-speaking Upper Canada (later <a href="/wiki/Ontario#Canada_West" title="Ontario">Ontario</a>), granting each its own elected legislative assembly.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons,_1813.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Painting of Laura Secord warning British commander James FitzGibbon of an impending American attack at Beaver Dams" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg/220px-Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg/330px-Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg/440px-Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="472"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons,_1813.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/War_of_1812" title="War of 1812">War of 1812</a> heroine <a href="/wiki/Laura_Secord" title="Laura Secord">Laura Secord</a> warning British commander <a href="/wiki/James_FitzGibbon" title="James FitzGibbon">James FitzGibbon</a> of an <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Beaver_Dams" title="Battle of Beaver Dams">impending American attack at Beaver Dams</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Canadas were the main front in the <a href="/wiki/War_of_1812" title="War of 1812">War of 1812</a> between the United States and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom</a>. Peace came in 1815; no boundaries were changed.<sup id="cite_ref-HarrisonFriesen2010_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HarrisonFriesen2010-65">[65]</a></sup> Immigration resumed at a higher level, with over 960,000 arrivals from Britain between 1815 and 1850.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> New arrivals included refugees escaping the <a href="/wiki/Great_Irish_Famine" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Irish Famine">Great Irish Famine</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">Gaelic</a>-speaking Scots displaced by the <a href="/wiki/Highland_Clearances" title="Highland Clearances">Highland Clearances</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> Infectious diseases killed between 25 and 33 percent of Europeans who immigrated to Canada before 1891.<sup id="cite_ref-dying_29-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dying-29">[29]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The desire for <a href="/wiki/Responsible_government" title="Responsible government">responsible government</a> resulted in the abortive <a href="/wiki/Rebellions_of_1837" class="mw-redirect" title="Rebellions of 1837">Rebellions of 1837</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Read1985_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Read1985-68">[68]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Report_on_the_Affairs_of_British_North_America" class="mw-redirect" title="Report on the Affairs of British North America">Durham Report</a> subsequently recommended responsible government and the assimilation of French Canadians into English culture.<sup id="cite_ref-buckner_20-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-buckner-20">[20]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Union_1840" title="Act of Union 1840">Act of Union 1840</a> merged the Canadas into a united Province of Canada and responsible government was established for all provinces of British North America by 1849.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> The signing of the <a href="/wiki/Oregon_Treaty" title="Oregon Treaty">Oregon Treaty</a> by Britain and <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Cession" title="Mexican Cession">the United States in 1846</a> ended the <a href="/wiki/Oregon_boundary_dispute" title="Oregon boundary dispute">Oregon boundary dispute</a>, extending the border westward along the <a href="/wiki/49th_parallel_north" title="49th parallel north">49th parallel</a>. This paved the way for British colonies on <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_Vancouver_Island" title="Colony of Vancouver Island">Vancouver Island (1849)</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_British_Columbia_(1858%E2%80%931866)" title="Colony of British Columbia (1858–1866)">British Columbia (1858)</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Alaska_Purchase" title="Alaska Purchase">Alaska Purchase</a> of 1867 by the United States established the border along the Pacific coast, although there would continue to be some disputes about the exact demarcation of the Alaska–Yukon and Alaska–BC border for years to come.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Confederation_and_expansion">Confederation and expansion</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif" class="image"><img alt="Refer to caption" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif/310px-Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif" decoding="async" width="310" height="268" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif/465px-Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif/620px-Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="864"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Animated map showing <a href="/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_Canada" title="Territorial evolution of Canada">the growth and change of Canada's provinces and territories</a> since Confederation in 1867
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Following several constitutional conferences, the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_Act,_1867" title="Constitution Act, 1867">British North America Act 1867</a> officially proclaimed Canadian Confederation on July 1, 1867, initially with four provinces: <a href="/wiki/Ontario" title="Ontario">Ontario</a>, Quebec, Nova Scotia, and New Brunswick.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bothwell_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bothwell-73">[73]</a></sup> Canada assumed control of <a href="/wiki/Rupert%27s_Land" title="Rupert's Land">Rupert's Land</a> and the <a href="/wiki/North-Western_Territory" title="North-Western Territory">North-Western Territory</a> to form the <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Territories" title="Northwest Territories">Northwest Territories</a>, where the Métis' grievances ignited the <a href="/wiki/Red_River_Rebellion" title="Red River Rebellion">Red River Rebellion</a> and the creation of the province of <a href="/wiki/Manitoba" title="Manitoba">Manitoba</a> in July 1870.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> British Columbia and Vancouver Island (which <a href="/wiki/United_Colonies_of_Vancouver_Island_and_British_Columbia" class="mw-redirect" title="United Colonies of Vancouver Island and British Columbia">had been united</a> in 1866) joined the confederation in 1871, while Prince Edward Island joined in 1873.<sup id="cite_ref-canatlas_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-canatlas-75">[75]</a></sup> In 1898, during the <a href="/wiki/Klondike_Gold_Rush" title="Klondike Gold Rush">Klondike Gold Rush</a> in the Northwest Territories, parliament created the Yukon Territory. <a href="/wiki/Alberta" title="Alberta">Alberta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saskatchewan" title="Saskatchewan">Saskatchewan</a> became provinces in 1905.<sup id="cite_ref-canatlas_75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-canatlas-75">[75]</a></sup> Between 1871 and 1896, almost one quarter of the Canadian population emigrated southwards, to the U.S.<sup id="cite_ref-mdmols_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mdmols-76">[76]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>To open <a href="/wiki/Western_Canada" title="Western Canada">the West</a> and encourage European immigration, Parliament approved sponsoring the construction of three transcontinental railways (including the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Pacific_Railway" title="Canadian Pacific Railway">Canadian Pacific Railway</a>), opening the prairies to settlement with the <i><a href="/wiki/Dominion_Lands_Act" title="Dominion Lands Act">Dominion Lands Act</a></i>, and establishing the <a href="/wiki/North-West_Mounted_Police" title="North-West Mounted Police">North-West Mounted Police</a> to assert its authority over this territory.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> This <a href="/wiki/Post-Confederation_Canada_(1867%E2%80%931914)#Expansion" title="Post-Confederation Canada (1867–1914)">period of westward expansion</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Policy" title="National Policy">nation building</a> resulted in the displacement of many <a href="/wiki/Plains_Indians" title="Plains Indians">Indigenous peoples of the Canadian Prairies</a> to "<a href="/wiki/Indian_reserve" title="Indian reserve">Indian reserves</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-Hele2013_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hele2013-79">[79]</a></sup> clearing the way for ethnic European <a href="/wiki/Block_settlement" title="Block settlement">block settlements</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> This caused the collapse of the <a href="/wiki/History_of_bison_conservation_in_Canada#Plains_bison" title="History of bison conservation in Canada">Plains Bison in western Canada</a> and the introduction of European <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Canada" title="Agriculture in Canada">cattle farms and wheat fields</a> dominating the land.<sup id="cite_ref-ArmitagePlummer2010_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArmitagePlummer2010-81">[81]</a></sup> The Indigenous peoples saw widespread famine and disease due to the loss of the bison and their traditional hunting lands <sup id="cite_ref-Daschuk2013_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Daschuk2013-82">[82]</a></sup> The federal government did provide emergency relief, on condition of the Indigenous peoples moving to the reserves.<sup id="cite_ref-Hall2015_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hall2015-83">[83]</a></sup> During this time, Canada introduced the <i><a href="/wiki/Indian_Act" title="Indian Act">Indian Act</a></i> extending its control over the First Nations to education, government and legal rights.<sup id="cite_ref-JacksonJackson2020_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JacksonJackson2020-84">[84]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_20th_century">Early 20th century</span></h3> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="theader">
          <span style="font-size:90%;">1918 <a href="/wiki/Canada_Savings_Bond" title="Canada Savings Bond">Canadian War bond posters</a> depicting three French women pulling a plow that had been constructed for horses.</span>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:144px;max-width:144px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:207px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg/142px-Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg" decoding="async" width="142" height="208" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg/213px-Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg/284px-Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2601" data-file-height="3806"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           French version of the poster roughly translates as "They serve France–Everyone can serve; Buy Victory Bonds".
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:144px;max-width:144px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:207px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg/142px-Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg" decoding="async" width="142" height="208" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg/213px-Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg/284px-Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2601" data-file-height="3805"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           The same poster in English, with subtle differences in text. "They serve France—How can I serve Canada? Buy Victory Bonds".
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Because Britain still maintained control of Canada's foreign affairs under the British North America Act, 1867, its declaration of war in 1914 automatically brought <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Canada_during_World_War_I" title="Military history of Canada during World War I">Canada into World War I</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> Volunteers sent to the <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western Front</a> later became part of the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Corps" title="Canadian Corps">Canadian Corps</a>, which played a substantial role in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vimy_Ridge" title="Battle of Vimy Ridge">Battle of Vimy Ridge</a> and other major engagements of the war.<sup id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup> Out of approximately 625,000 Canadians who served in World War I, some 60,000 were killed and another 172,000 were wounded.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Conscription_Crisis_of_1917" title="Conscription Crisis of 1917">Conscription Crisis of 1917</a> erupted when the <a href="/wiki/Unionist_Party_(Canada)" title="Unionist Party (Canada)">Unionist</a> Cabinet's proposal to augment the military's dwindling number of active members with <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscription</a> was met with vehement objections from French-speaking Quebecers.<sup id="cite_ref-McGonigal1962_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McGonigal1962-88">[88]</a></sup> The <i>Military Service Act</i> brought in compulsory military service, though it, coupled with disputes over French language schools outside Quebec, deeply alienated Francophone Canadians and temporarily split the Liberal Party.<sup id="cite_ref-McGonigal1962_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McGonigal1962-88">[88]</a></sup> In 1919, Canada joined the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> independently of Britain,<sup id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_1931" title="Statute of Westminster 1931">Statute of Westminster 1931</a> affirmed Canada's independence.<sup id="cite_ref-Morton2002_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morton2002-89">[89]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression_in_Canada" title="Great Depression in Canada">Great Depression in Canada</a> during the early 1930s saw an economic downturn, leading to hardship across the country.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> In response to the downturn, the <a href="/wiki/Co-operative_Commonwealth_Federation" title="Co-operative Commonwealth Federation">Co-operative Commonwealth Federation</a> (CCF) in Saskatchewan introduced many elements of a <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a> (as pioneered by <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Douglas" title="Tommy Douglas">Tommy Douglas</a>) in the 1940s and 1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> On the advice of Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/William_Lyon_Mackenzie_King" title="William Lyon Mackenzie King">William Lyon Mackenzie King</a>, <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_war_by_Canada#Nazi_Germany" title="Declaration of war by Canada">war with Germany was declared</a> effective September 10, 1939, by King <a href="/wiki/George_VI" title="George VI">George VI</a>, seven days after the United Kingdom. The delay underscored Canada's independence.<sup id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The first Canadian Army units arrived in Britain in December 1939. In all, over a million Canadians served in the armed forces during World War II and approximately 42,000 were killed and another 55,000 were wounded.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Canadian troops played important roles in many key battles of the war, including the failed 1942 <a href="/wiki/Dieppe_Raid" title="Dieppe Raid">Dieppe Raid</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Allied_invasion_of_Italy" title="Allied invasion of Italy">Allied invasion of Italy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Normandy_landings" title="Normandy landings">Normandy landings</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Overlord" title="Operation Overlord">Battle of Normandy</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Scheldt" title="Battle of the Scheldt">Battle of the Scheldt</a> in 1944.<sup id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup> Canada provided asylum for the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_monarchy" class="mw-redirect" title="Dutch monarchy">Dutch monarchy</a> while that country was <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissariat_Niederlande" title="Reichskommissariat Niederlande">occupied</a> and is credited by the Netherlands for major contributions to <a href="/wiki/Liberation_Day_(Netherlands)" title="Liberation Day (Netherlands)">its liberation</a> from <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-netherlands_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-netherlands-93">[93]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Canadian economy boomed during the war as its industries manufactured military <a href="/wiki/Materiel" title="Materiel">materiel</a> for Canada, Britain, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%9349)" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of China (1912–49)">China</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup> Despite another <a href="/wiki/Conscription_Crisis_of_1944" title="Conscription Crisis of 1944">Conscription Crisis</a> in Quebec in 1944, Canada finished the war with a large army and strong economy.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_era">Contemporary era</span></h3> 
      <p>The financial crisis of the Great Depression had led the <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Newfoundland" title="Dominion of Newfoundland">Dominion of Newfoundland</a> to relinquish responsible government in 1934 and become a <a href="/wiki/Crown_colony" title="Crown colony">crown colony</a> ruled by a British governor.<sup id="cite_ref-Buckner20082ed_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buckner20082ed-95">[95]</a></sup> After two <a href="/wiki/1948_Newfoundland_referendums" title="1948 Newfoundland referendums">referendums</a>, Newfoundlanders voted to join Canada in 1949 as a province.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada's post-war economic growth, combined with the policies of successive Liberal governments, led to the emergence of a new <a href="/wiki/Canadian_identity" title="Canadian identity">Canadian identity</a>, marked by the adoption of the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Canada" title="Flag of Canada">Maple Leaf Flag</a> in 1965,<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> the implementation of <a href="/wiki/Official_bilingualism" class="mw-redirect" title="Official bilingualism">official bilingualism</a> (English and French) in 1969,<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> and the institution of <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism#Canada" title="Multiculturalism">official multiculturalism</a> in 1971.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Social_democracy" title="Social democracy">Socially democratic</a> programs were also instituted, such as <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(Canada)" title="Medicare (Canada)">Medicare</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Canada_Pension_Plan" title="Canada Pension Plan">Canada Pension Plan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Student_loans_in_Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="Student loans in Canada">Canada Student Loans</a>, though provincial governments, particularly Quebec and Alberta, opposed many of these as incursions into their jurisdictions.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> </p> 
      <p><i>[[</i></p><i>
       <div class="thumb tright">
        <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
         <a href="/wiki/File:Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg" class="image"><img alt="refer to caption" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg/220px-Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg/330px-Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a4/Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="309"></a> 
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <div class="magnify">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
          </div>A copy of the <i><a href="/wiki/Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms" title="Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms">Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms</a></i>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div></i> 
      <p>Finally, another series of constitutional conferences resulted in the UK's <a href="/wiki/Canada_Act_1982" title="Canada Act 1982">Canada Act 1982</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Patriation" title="Patriation">patriation</a> of Canada's constitution from the United Kingdom, concurrent with the creation of the <i><a href="/wiki/Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms" title="Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms">Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> Canada had established complete sovereignty as an independent country, although the Queen retained her role as monarch of Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bickerton_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bickerton-105">[105]</a></sup> In 1999, <a href="/wiki/Nunavut" title="Nunavut">Nunavut</a> became Canada's third territory after a series of negotiations with the federal government.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At the same time, Quebec underwent profound social and economic changes through the <a href="/wiki/Quiet_Revolution" title="Quiet Revolution">Quiet Revolution</a> of the 1960s, giving birth to a secular <a href="/wiki/Quebec_nationalism" title="Quebec nationalism">nationalist</a> movement.<sup id="cite_ref-RobertsClifton2005_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RobertsClifton2005-107">[107]</a></sup> The radical <a href="/wiki/Front_de_lib%C3%A9ration_du_Qu%C3%A9bec" title="Front de libération du Québec">Front de libération du Québec</a> (FLQ) ignited the <a href="/wiki/October_Crisis" title="October Crisis">October Crisis</a> with a series of bombings and kidnappings in 1970<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Quebec_sovereignty_movement" title="Quebec sovereignty movement">sovereignist</a> <a href="/wiki/Parti_Qu%C3%A9b%C3%A9cois" title="Parti Québécois">Parti Québécois</a> was elected in 1976, organizing an <a href="/wiki/1980_Quebec_referendum" title="1980 Quebec referendum">unsuccessful referendum</a> on sovereignty-association in 1980. Attempts to accommodate Quebec nationalism constitutionally through the <a href="/wiki/Meech_Lake_Accord" title="Meech Lake Accord">Meech Lake Accord</a> failed in 1990.<sup id="cite_ref-sorens_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sorens-109">[109]</a></sup> This led to the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Bloc_Qu%C3%A9b%C3%A9cois" title="Bloc Québécois">Bloc Québécois</a> in Quebec and the invigoration of the <a href="/wiki/Reform_Party_of_Canada" title="Reform Party of Canada">Reform Party of Canada</a> in the West.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/1995_Quebec_referendum" title="1995 Quebec referendum">second referendum</a> followed in 1995, in which sovereignty was rejected by a slimmer margin of 50.6 to 49.4 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> In 1997, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Canada" title="Supreme Court of Canada">Supreme Court</a> ruled <a href="/wiki/Reference_re_Secession_of_Quebec" class="mw-redirect" title="Reference re Secession of Quebec">unilateral secession</a> by a province would be unconstitutional and the <i><a href="/wiki/Clarity_Act" title="Clarity Act">Clarity Act</a></i> was passed by parliament, outlining the terms of a negotiated departure from Confederation.<sup id="cite_ref-sorens_109-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sorens-109">[109]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In addition to the issues of Quebec sovereignty, a number of crises shook Canadian society in the late 1980s and early 1990s. These included the explosion of <a href="/wiki/Air_India_Flight_182" title="Air India Flight 182">Air India Flight 182</a> in 1985, the largest mass murder in Canadian history;<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_Polytechnique_massacre" title="École Polytechnique massacre">École Polytechnique massacre</a> in 1989, a <a href="/wiki/School_shooting" title="School shooting">university shooting</a> targeting female students;<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Oka_Crisis" title="Oka Crisis">Oka Crisis</a> of 1990,<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> the first of a number of violent confrontations between the government and Indigenous groups.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> Canada also joined the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a> in 1990 as part of a United States–led coalition force and was active in several peacekeeping missions in the 1990s, including the <a href="/wiki/UNPROFOR" class="mw-redirect" title="UNPROFOR">UNPROFOR</a> mission in the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Yugoslav wars">former Yugoslavia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada sent <a href="/wiki/Canada_in_the_War_in_Afghanistan" title="Canada in the War in Afghanistan">troops to Afghanistan in 2001</a>, but declined to join the United States–led <a href="/wiki/2003_Invasion_of_Iraq" class="mw-redirect" title="2003 Invasion of Iraq">invasion of Iraq in 2003</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> In 2011, Canadian forces participated in the NATO-led intervention into the <a href="/wiki/Libyan_Civil_War_(2011)" class="mw-redirect" title="Libyan Civil War (2011)">Libyan Civil War</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-HehirMurray2013_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HehirMurray2013-119">[119]</a></sup> and also became involved in battling the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">Islamic State</a> insurgency in Iraq in the mid-2010s.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Canada" title="Geography of Canada">Geography of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Canada_topo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="refer to caption" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Canada_topo.jpg/310px-Canada_topo.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="268" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Canada_topo.jpg/465px-Canada_topo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Canada_topo.jpg/620px-Canada_topo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="1211"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Canada_topo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A topographic map of Canada, in polar projection (for 90° W), showing elevations shaded from green to brown (higher)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By total area (including its waters), Canada is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_total_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries and outlying territories by total area">second-largest country</a> in the world, after <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BresciaSuper2009_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BresciaSuper2009-121">[121]</a></sup> By land area alone, however, Canada <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_land_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries and outlying territories by land area">ranks fourth</a>, due to having the world's largest proportion of <a href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_of_Canada" title="List of lakes of Canada">fresh water lakes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Battram2010da_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Battram2010da-122">[122]</a></sup> Stretching from the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> in the east, along the <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Ocean" title="Arctic Ocean">Arctic Ocean</a> to the north, and to the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> in the west, the country encompasses 9,984,670&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (3,855,100&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) of territory.<sup id="cite_ref-McColl2005_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McColl2005-123">[123]</a></sup> Canada also has vast maritime terrain, with the world's longest coastline of 243,042 kilometres (151,019&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> In addition to sharing the <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_border" title="Canada–United States border">world's largest land border with the United States</a>—spanning 8,891&nbsp;km (5,525&nbsp;mi)—Canada shares a <a href="/wiki/Maritime_boundary" title="Maritime boundary">maritime boundary</a> with Greenland to the northeast and with the <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Overseas_collectivity" title="Overseas collectivity">overseas collectivity</a> of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Pierre_and_Miquelon" title="Saint Pierre and Miquelon">Saint Pierre and Miquelon</a> to the southeast.<sup id="cite_ref-Gallay2015_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gallay2015-126">[126]</a></sup> Canada is also home to the world's northernmost settlement, <a href="/wiki/CFS_Alert" title="CFS Alert">Canadian Forces Station Alert</a>, on the northern tip of <a href="/wiki/Ellesmere_Island" title="Ellesmere Island">Ellesmere Island</a>—latitude 82.5°N—which lies 817 kilometres (508&nbsp;mi) from the North Pole.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Canada#Physical_geography" title="Geography of Canada">physical geography of Canada</a> is widely varied. <a href="/wiki/Taiga" title="Taiga">Boreal forests</a> prevail throughout the country, ice is prominent in <a href="/wiki/Northern_Canada" title="Northern Canada">northern Arctic regions</a> and through the <a href="/wiki/Rocky_Mountains" title="Rocky Mountains">Rocky Mountains</a>, and the relatively flat <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Prairies" title="Canadian Prairies">Canadian Prairies</a> in the southwest facilitate <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Canada" title="Agriculture in Canada">productive agriculture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-McColl2005_123-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McColl2005-123">[123]</a></sup> The Great Lakes feed the <a href="/wiki/St._Lawrence_River" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Lawrence River">St. Lawrence River</a> (in the southeast) where the lowlands host much of Canada's economic output.<sup id="cite_ref-McColl2005_123-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McColl2005-123">[123]</a></sup> Canada has over 2,000,000 lakes—563 of which are greater than 100&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (39&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi)—containing much of the world's <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">fresh water</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> There are also fresh-water glaciers in the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Rockies" title="Canadian Rockies">Canadian Rockies</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Coast_Mountains" title="Coast Mountains">Coast Mountains</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Cordillera" title="Arctic Cordillera">Arctic Cordillera</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sandford2012_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sandford2012-130">[130]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_Canada" title="Geology of Canada">Canada is geologically</a> active, having <a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_Canada" title="List of earthquakes in Canada">many earthquakes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volcanism_of_Canada" title="Volcanism of Canada">potentially active volcanoes</a>, notably <a href="/wiki/Mount_Meager_massif" title="Mount Meager massif">Mount Meager massif</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Garibaldi" title="Mount Garibaldi">Mount Garibaldi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Cayley_massif" title="Mount Cayley massif">Mount Cayley massif</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Mount_Edziza_volcanic_complex" title="Mount Edziza volcanic complex">Mount Edziza volcanic complex</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity_and_climate">Biodiversity and climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Canada" title="Wildlife of Canada">Wildlife of Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Temperature_in_Canada" title="Temperature in Canada">Temperature in Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada,_2017.gif" class="image"><img alt="Map showing Canada divided into different ecozones" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif/310px-Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif" decoding="async" width="310" height="265" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif/465px-Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif/620px-Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif 2x" data-file-width="710" data-file-height="606"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
