         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada,_2017.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ecozones_of_Canada" title="Ecozones of Canada">Terrestrial ecozones and ecoprovinces of Canada.</a>. Ecozone are identified with a unique colour. Ecoprovinces are subdivisions of ecozones and are identified with a unique numeric code
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Canada is divided into <a href="/wiki/Ecozones_of_Canada" title="Ecozones of Canada">fifteen terrestrial and five marine ecozones</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-intro_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-intro-132">[132]</a></sup> These ecozones encompass over 80,000 classified species of <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Canada" title="Wildlife of Canada">Canadian wildlife</a>, with an equal number yet to be formally recognized or discovered.<sup id="cite_ref-Species_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Species-133">[133]</a></sup> Over half of Canada's landscape is intact and relatively free of human development.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Boreal_forest_of_Canada" title="Boreal forest of Canada">boreal forest of Canada</a> is considered to be the largest <a href="/wiki/Intact_forest_landscape" title="Intact forest landscape">intact forest</a> on Earth, with approximately 3,000,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,200,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) undisturbed by roads, cities or industry.<sup id="cite_ref-RavenBerg2012_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RavenBerg2012-135">[135]</a></sup> Since the end of the last <a href="/wiki/Glacial_period" title="Glacial period">glacial period</a>, Canada has consisted of <a href="/wiki/Forests_of_Canada#Regions" title="Forests of Canada">eight distinct forest regions</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> with 42 percent of its land area covered by forests (approximately 8 percent of the world's forested land), made up mostly of <a href="/wiki/Spruce" title="Spruce">spruce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Populus" title="Populus">poplar</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pine" title="Pine">pine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-LuckertHaley2011_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LuckertHaley2011-137">[137]</a></sup> Approximately 12.1 percent of the nation's landmass and freshwater are <a href="/wiki/National_Wildlife_Area" title="National Wildlife Area">conservation areas</a>, including 11.4 percent designated as <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Canada" title="Protected areas of Canada">protected areas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-conserved_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-conserved-138">[138]</a></sup> Approximately 13.8 percent of its territorial waters are conserved, including 8.9 percent designated as protected areas.<sup id="cite_ref-conserved_138-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-conserved-138">[138]</a></sup> Due to human activities, invasive species and <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Canada" title="Environmental issues in Canada">environmental issues in the country</a>, there are currently more than <a href="/wiki/List_of_Wildlife_Species_at_Risk_(Canada)" title="List of Wildlife Species at Risk (Canada)">800 species at risk of being lost</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-COSEWIC_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COSEWIC-139">[139]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Average winter and summer high <a href="/wiki/Temperature_in_Canada" title="Temperature in Canada">temperatures across Canada</a> vary from region to region. Winters can be harsh in many parts of the country, particularly in the interior and Prairie provinces, which experience a <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental climate</a>, where daily average temperatures are near −15&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">°C</a> (5&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">°F</a>), but can drop below −40&nbsp;°C (−40&nbsp;°F) with severe <a href="/wiki/Wind_chill" title="Wind chill">wind chills</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> In non-coastal regions, snow can cover the ground for almost six months of the year, while in parts of the north snow can persist year-round. Coastal British Columbia has a temperate climate, with a mild and rainy winter. On the east and west coasts, average high temperatures are generally in the low 20s °C (70s °F), while between the coasts, the average summer high temperature ranges from 25 to 30&nbsp;°C (77 to 86&nbsp;°F), with temperatures in some interior locations occasionally exceeding 40&nbsp;°C (104&nbsp;°F).<sup id="cite_ref-ccnRegina_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ccnRegina-141">[141]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Much of <a href="/wiki/Northern_Canada" title="Northern Canada">Northern Canada</a> is covered by ice and <a href="/wiki/Permafrost" title="Permafrost">permafrost</a>; however, the future of the permafrost is uncertain because the Arctic has been warming at three times the global average as a result of <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Canada" title="Climate change in Canada">climate change in Canada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> Canada's annual average temperature over land has warmed by 1.7&nbsp;°C (3.1&nbsp;°F), with changes ranging from 1.1 to 2.3&nbsp;°C (2.0 to 4.1&nbsp;°F) in various regions, since 1948.<sup id="cite_ref-ClimateReport_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ClimateReport-143">[143]</a></sup> The rate of warming has been higher across the North and in the Prairies.<sup id="cite_ref-ClimateReport_143-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ClimateReport-143">[143]</a></sup> In the southern regions of Canada, <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution_in_Canada" title="Air pollution in Canada">air pollution</a> from both Canada and the United States—caused by metal smelting, burning coal to power utilities, and vehicle emissions—has resulted in <a href="/wiki/Acid_rain" title="Acid rain">acid rain</a>, which has severely impacted waterways, forest growth and agricultural productivity in Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-Boyd2011_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boyd2011-144">[144]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Canada" title="Government of Canada">Government of Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Canada" title="Politics of Canada">Politics of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Canada is described as a "<a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index#Classification_definitions" title="Democracy Index">full democracy</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> with a tradition of <a href="/wiki/Liberalism" title="Liberalism">liberalism</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-WesthuesWharf2014_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WesthuesWharf2014-146">[146]</a></sup> and an <a href="/wiki/Egalitarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Egalitarian">egalitarian</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-BickertonGagnon2009_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BickertonGagnon2009-147">[147]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Moderate" title="Moderate">moderate</a> political ideology.<sup id="cite_ref-Johnson2016_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson2016-148">[148]</a></sup> An emphasis on <a href="/wiki/Social_justice" title="Social justice">social justice</a> has been a distinguishing element of Canada's political culture.<sup id="cite_ref-Fierlbeck2006_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fierlbeck2006-149">[149]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Peace,_order,_and_good_government" title="Peace, order, and good government">Peace, order, and good government</a>, alongside an <a href="/wiki/Implied_bill_of_rights" class="mw-redirect" title="Implied bill of rights">implied bill of rights</a> are founding principles of the Canadian government.<sup id="cite_ref-DixonScheurell2016_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DixonScheurell2016-150">[150]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Boughey2017_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boughey2017-151">[151]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Parliamenthill.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A building with a central clock tower rising from a block" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Parliamenthill.jpg/220px-Parliamenthill.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Parliamenthill.jpg/330px-Parliamenthill.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Parliamenthill.jpg/440px-Parliamenthill.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4260" data-file-height="3220"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Parliamenthill.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Parliament_Hill" title="Parliament Hill">Parliament Hill</a>, home of the federal government in Canada's capital city, <a href="/wiki/Ottawa" title="Ottawa">Ottawa</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>At the federal level, Canada has been dominated by two relatively <a href="/wiki/Centrist" class="mw-redirect" title="Centrist">centrist</a> parties practicing "brokerage politics",<sup id="cite_ref-politics_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-politics-155">[a]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Brooks2004_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brooks2004-156">[155]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Smith2014_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Smith2014-157">[156]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Johnson2016c_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson2016c-158">[157]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Centre-left" class="mw-redirect" title="Centre-left">centre-left</a> leaning <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Canada" title="Liberal Party of Canada">Liberal Party of Canada</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Centre-right" class="mw-redirect" title="Centre-right">centre-right</a> leaning <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_of_Canada" title="Conservative Party of Canada">Conservative Party of Canada</a> (or its <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_of_Canada#Predecessors" title="Conservative Party of Canada">predecessors</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-BaumerGold2015_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BaumerGold2015-159">[158]</a></sup> The historically predominant Liberal Party position themselves at the centre of the Canadian political spectrum,<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[159]</a></sup> with the Conservative Party positioned on the right and the <a href="/wiki/New_Democratic_Party" title="New Democratic Party">New Democratic Party</a> occupying the <a href="/wiki/Left-wing" class="mw-redirect" title="Left-wing">left</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EvansGraaf2013_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EvansGraaf2013-161">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Johnston2017_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnston2017-162">[161]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Far-right" class="mw-redirect" title="Far-right">Far-right</a> and <a href="/wiki/Far-left" class="mw-redirect" title="Far-left">far-left</a> politics have never been a prominent force in Canadian society.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[162]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[163]</a></sup> Five parties had representatives elected to the federal parliament in the <a href="/wiki/2019_Canadian_federal_election" title="2019 Canadian federal election">2019 election</a>—the Liberal Party, who currently form a minority government; the Conservative Party, who are the <a href="/wiki/Official_Opposition_(Canada)" title="Official Opposition (Canada)">Official Opposition</a>; the New Democratic Party; the Bloc Québécois; and the <a href="/wiki/Green_Party_of_Canada" title="Green Party of Canada">Green Party of Canada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[164]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada has a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a> within the context of a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>—the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Canada" title="Monarchy of Canada">monarchy of Canada</a> being the foundation of the executive, <a href="/wiki/Legislative" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative">legislative</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Judicial" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial">judicial</a> branches.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MacLeod16_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacLeod16-168">[167]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Reign" title="Reign">reigning</a> monarch is <a href="/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Queen Elizabeth II">Queen Elizabeth II</a>, who is also monarch of 15 other <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="Commonwealth countries">Commonwealth countries</a> and each of Canada's 10 provinces. The person who is the Canadian monarch is the same as the <a href="/wiki/British_monarch" class="mw-redirect" title="British monarch">British monarch</a>, although the two institutions are separate.<sup id="cite_ref-Johnson2018_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson2018-169">[168]</a></sup> The monarch appoints a representative, the <a href="/wiki/Governor_General_of_Canada" title="Governor General of Canada">governor general</a>, to carry out most of her federal royal duties in Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[170]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The direct participation of the monarch and the governor general in areas of governance is limited.<sup id="cite_ref-MacLeod16_168-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacLeod16-168">[167]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Forseyp1_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forseyp1-172">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Montpetit_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Montpetit-173">[172]</a></sup> In practice, their use of the executive powers is directed by the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Canada" title="Cabinet of Canada">Cabinet</a>, a committee of <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_the_Crown" title="Minister of the Crown">ministers of the Crown</a> responsible to the elected <a href="/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_Canada" title="House of Commons of Canada">House of Commons of Canada</a> and chosen and headed by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Canada" title="Prime Minister of Canada">prime minister</a> (at present <a href="/wiki/Justin_Trudeau" title="Justin Trudeau">Justin Trudeau</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[173]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>. The governor general or monarch may, though, in certain crisis situations exercise their power without ministerial <a href="/wiki/Advice_(constitutional)" title="Advice (constitutional)">advice</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Forseyp1_172-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forseyp1-172">[171]</a></sup> To ensure the stability of government, the governor general will usually appoint as prime minister the individual who is the current leader of the political party that can obtain the confidence of a <a href="/wiki/Plurality_(voting)" title="Plurality (voting)">plurality</a> in the House of Commons.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[174]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_Prime_Minister_(Canada)" title="Office of the Prime Minister (Canada)">Prime Minister's Office</a> (PMO) is thus one of the most powerful institutions in government, initiating most legislation for parliamentary approval and selecting for appointment by the Crown, besides the aforementioned, the governor general, <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_governor_(Canada)" title="Lieutenant governor (Canada)">lieutenant governors</a>, senators, federal court judges, and heads of <a href="/wiki/Crown_corporations_of_Canada" title="Crown corporations of Canada">Crown corporations</a> and government agencies.<sup id="cite_ref-Forseyp1_172-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forseyp1-172">[171]</a></sup> The leader of the party with the second-most seats usually becomes the <a href="/wiki/Leader_of_the_Official_Opposition_(Canada)" title="Leader of the Official Opposition (Canada)">leader of Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition</a> and is part of an adversarial parliamentary system intended to keep the government in check.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[175]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cansenate.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Canadian Senate chamber long hall with two opposing banks of seats with historical paintings" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Cansenate.jpg/220px-Cansenate.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="143" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Cansenate.jpg/330px-Cansenate.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Cansenate.jpg/440px-Cansenate.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1310" data-file-height="854"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cansenate.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Canada" title="Senate of Canada">Senate chamber</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Centre_Block" title="Centre Block">Centre Block</a> on <a href="/wiki/Parliament_Hill" title="Parliament Hill">Parliament Hill</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Each of the 338 members of parliament in the House of Commons is elected by simple plurality in an <a href="/wiki/Canadian_electoral_district" class="mw-redirect" title="Canadian electoral district">electoral district</a> or riding. <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Canada" title="Elections in Canada">General elections</a> must be called by the governor general, either on the advice of the prime minister or if the government loses a <a href="/wiki/Confidence_vote" class="mw-redirect" title="Confidence vote">confidence vote</a> in the House.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[176]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[177]</a></sup> Constitutionally, an election may be held no more than five years after the preceding election, although the <i><a href="/wiki/Canada_Elections_Act" title="Canada Elections Act">Canada Elections Act</a></i> limits this to four years with a fixed election date in October. The 105 members of the Senate, whose seats are apportioned on a regional basis, serve until age 75.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[178]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Canada%27s_federal_structure" class="mw-redirect" title="Canada's federal structure">Canada's federal structure</a> divides government responsibilities between the federal government and the ten provinces. <a href="/wiki/Legislative_assemblies_of_Canadian_provinces_and_territories" title="Legislative assemblies of Canadian provinces and territories">Provincial legislatures</a> are <a href="/wiki/Unicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> and operate in parliamentary fashion similar to the House of Commons.<sup id="cite_ref-Montpetit_173-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Montpetit-173">[172]</a></sup> Canada's three territories also have legislatures, but these are not sovereign and have fewer constitutional responsibilities than the provinces.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[179]</a></sup> The territorial legislatures also differ structurally from their provincial counterparts.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[180]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Canada" title="Bank of Canada">Bank of Canada</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Central_bank" title="Central bank">central bank</a> of the country. In addition, the <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_Finance_(Canada)" title="Minister of Finance (Canada)">minister of finance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_Industry_(Canada)" class="mw-redirect" title="Minister of Industry (Canada)">minister of industry</a> utilize the <a href="/wiki/Statistics_Canada" title="Statistics Canada">Statistics Canada</a> agency for financial planning and economic policy development.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[181]</a></sup> The Bank of Canada is the sole authority authorized to issue currency in the form of <a href="/wiki/Banknotes_of_the_Canadian_dollar" title="Banknotes of the Canadian dollar">Canadian bank notes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GilbertHelleiner2003_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GilbertHelleiner2003-183">[182]</a></sup> The bank does not issue <a href="/wiki/Coins_of_the_Canadian_dollar" title="Coins of the Canadian dollar">Canadian coins</a>; they are issued by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Mint" title="Royal Canadian Mint">Royal Canadian Mint</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CuhajMichael2011_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CuhajMichael2011-184">[183]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Canada" title="Law of Canada">Law of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Canada" title="Constitution of Canada">Constitution of Canada</a> is the supreme law of the country, and consists of written text and unwritten conventions.<sup id="cite_ref-Dodek2016_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dodek2016-185">[184]</a></sup> The <i>Constitution Act, 1867</i> (known as the <i><a href="/wiki/British_North_America_Acts" title="British North America Acts">British North America Act</a></i> prior to 1982), affirmed governance based on parliamentary precedent and divided powers between the federal and provincial governments.<sup id="cite_ref-Olive2015_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Olive2015-186">[185]</a></sup> The Statute of Westminster 1931 granted full autonomy and the <i><a href="/wiki/Constitution_Act,_1982" title="Constitution Act, 1982">Constitution Act, 1982</a></i>, ended all legislative ties to Britain, as well as adding a constitutional amending formula and the <i>Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-VishnooShirur1997_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VishnooShirur1997-187">[186]</a></sup> The Charter guarantees basic rights and freedoms that usually cannot be over-ridden by any government—though a <a href="/wiki/Section_Thirty-three_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms" class="mw-redirect" title="Section Thirty-three of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms">notwithstanding clause</a> allows the federal parliament and provincial legislatures to override certain sections of the <i>Charter</i> for a period of five years.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[187]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Supreme Court of Canada building" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg/220px-Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="130" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg/330px-Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg/440px-Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="2360"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Canada" title="Supreme Court of Canada">Supreme Court of Canada</a> in Ottawa, west of Parliament Hill
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Court_system_of_Canada" title="Court system of Canada">Canada's judiciary</a> plays an important role in interpreting laws and has the power to strike down Acts of Parliament that violate the constitution. The Supreme Court of Canada is the highest court and final arbiter and has been led since December 18, 2017 by Chief Justice <a href="/wiki/Richard_Wagner_(judge)" title="Richard Wagner (judge)">Richard Wagner</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[188]</a></sup> Its nine members are appointed by the governor general on the advice of the prime minister and minister of justice. All judges at the superior and appellate levels are appointed after consultation with non-governmental legal bodies. The federal Cabinet also appoints justices to superior courts in the provincial and territorial jurisdictions.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[189]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">Common law</a> prevails everywhere except in Quebec, where <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> predominates. <a href="/wiki/Criminal_law_of_Canada" title="Criminal law of Canada">Criminal law</a> is solely a federal responsibility and is uniform throughout Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[190]</a></sup> Law enforcement, including criminal courts, is officially a provincial responsibility, conducted by provincial and municipal police forces.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[191]</a></sup> However, in most rural areas and some urban areas, policing responsibilities are contracted to the federal <a href="/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Mounted_Police" title="Royal Canadian Mounted Police">Royal Canadian Mounted Police</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[192]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Canadian_Aboriginal_law" title="Canadian Aboriginal law">Canadian Aboriginal law</a> provides certain <a href="/wiki/Aboriginal_land_title_in_Canada" title="Aboriginal land title in Canada">constitutionally recognized rights to land</a> and traditional practices for Indigenous groups in Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-Reynolds2015_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reynolds2015-194">[193]</a></sup> Various treaties and case laws were established to mediate relations between Europeans and many Indigenous peoples.<sup id="cite_ref-FN_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FN-195">[194]</a></sup> Most notably, a series of eleven treaties known as the <a href="/wiki/Numbered_Treaties" title="Numbered Treaties">Numbered Treaties</a> were signed between the Indigenous peoples and the reigning monarch of Canada between 1871 and 1921.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[195]</a></sup> These treaties are agreements between the Canadian <a href="/wiki/Queen-in-Council" class="mw-redirect" title="Queen-in-Council">Crown-in-Council</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Duty_to_consult_and_accommodate" title="Duty to consult and accommodate">duty to consult and accommodate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Isaac2012_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaac2012-197">[196]</a></sup> The role of Aboriginal law and the rights they support were reaffirmed by <a href="/wiki/Section_35_of_the_Constitution_Act,_1982" title="Section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982">Section 35 of the <i>Constitution Act, 1982</i></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FN_195-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FN-195">[194]</a></sup> These rights may include provision of services, such as health care through the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Health_Transfer_Policy" title="Indian Health Transfer Policy">Indian Health Transfer Policy</a>, and exemption from taxation.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[197]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations_and_military">Foreign relations and military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Canada" title="Foreign relations of Canada">Foreign relations of Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Armed_Forces" title="Canadian Armed Forces">Canadian Armed Forces</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Canada" title="Military history of Canada">Military history of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Canadian Delegation to the United Nations seated around conference table" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg/220px-Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg/330px-Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg/440px-Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg 2x" data-file-width="760" data-file-height="560"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Canadian delegation to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Conference_on_International_Organization" title="United Nations Conference on International Organization">United Nations Conference on International Organization</a>, San Francisco, May 1945
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Canada is recognized as a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a> for its role in international affairs with a tendency to pursue <a href="/wiki/Multilateralism" title="Multilateralism">multilateral</a> solutions.<sup id="cite_ref-Chapnick2011a_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chapnick2011a-199">[198]</a></sup> Canada's foreign policy based on international peacekeeping and security is carried out through coalitions and international organizations, and through the work of numerous federal institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-SensStoett2013a_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SensStoett2013a-200">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[200]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Canadian_peacekeeping" class="mw-redirect" title="Canadian peacekeeping">Canada's peacekeeping role</a> during the 20th century has played a major role in its global image.<sup id="cite_ref-SorensonWood2005_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SorensonWood2005-202">[201]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SobelShiraev2002b_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SobelShiraev2002b-203">[202]</a></sup> The strategy of the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Canada#Foreign_aid" title="Foreign relations of Canada">Canadian government's foreign aid policy</a> reflects an emphasis to meet the <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Development_Goals" title="Millennium Development Goals">Millennium Development Goals</a>, while also providing assistance in response to foreign humanitarian crises.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[203]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada was a founding member of the United Nations and has membership in the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD).<sup id="cite_ref-Chapnick2011a_199-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chapnick2011a-199">[198]</a></sup> Canada is also a member of various other international and regional organizations and forums for economic and cultural affairs.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[204]</a></sup> Canada acceded to the <a href="/wiki/International_Covenant_on_Civil_and_Political_Rights" title="International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights">International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights</a> in 1976.<sup id="cite_ref-Clément2016_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Clément2016-206">[205]</a></sup> Canada joined the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a> (OAS) in 1990 and hosted the OAS General Assembly in 2000 and the <a href="/wiki/3rd_Summit_of_the_Americas" title="3rd Summit of the Americas">3rd Summit of the Americas</a> in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[206]</a></sup> Canada seeks to expand its ties to <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Rim" title="Pacific Rim">Pacific Rim</a> economies through membership in the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> forum (APEC).<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[207]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Canada–United States relations">Canada and the United States</a> share the world's longest undefended border, co-operate on military campaigns and exercises, and are each other's <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_trade_relations" title="Canada–United States trade relations">largest trading partner</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[209]</a></sup> Canada nevertheless has an independent foreign policy, most notably maintaining full <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93Cuba_relations" title="Canada–Cuba relations">relations with Cuba</a>, and declining to officially participate in the <a href="/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq" title="2003 invasion of Iraq">2003 invasion of Iraq</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BickertonGagnon2014_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BickertonGagnon2014-211">[210]</a></sup> Canada also maintains historic ties to the <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations" title="Canada–United Kingdom relations">United Kingdom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93France_relations" title="Canada–France relations">France</a> and to other former British and French colonies through Canada's membership in the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">Francophonie</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[211]</a></sup> Canada is noted for having a positive <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93Netherlands_relations" title="Canada–Netherlands relations">relationship with the Netherlands</a>, owing, in part, to its contribution to the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_in_World_War_II#Liberation" title="Netherlands in World War II">Dutch liberation during World War II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-netherlands_93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-netherlands-93">[93]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada's strong attachment to the British Empire and Commonwealth led to major participation in British military efforts in the <a href="/wiki/Second_Boer_War" title="Second Boer War">Second Boer War</a>, World War I and World War II.<sup id="cite_ref-DeRouen_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DeRouen-213">[212]</a></sup> Since then, Canada has been an advocate for multilateralism, making efforts to resolve global issues in collaboration with other nations.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[214]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Canada_in_the_Cold_War" title="Canada in the Cold War">Cold War</a>, Canada was a major contributor to UN forces in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a> and founded the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Aerospace_Defense_Command" title="North American Aerospace Defense Command">North American Aerospace Defense Command</a> (NORAD) in cooperation with the United States to defend against potential aerial attacks from the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[215]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A fighter jet taking off from a runway" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg/220px-CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg/330px-CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg/440px-CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1295" data-file-height="904"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A Canadian <a href="/wiki/CF-18_Hornet" class="mw-redirect" title="CF-18 Hornet">CF-18 Hornet</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cold_Lake,_Alberta" title="Cold Lake, Alberta">Cold Lake, Alberta</a>. CF-18s have supported <a href="/wiki/North_American_Aerospace_Defense_Command" title="North American Aerospace Defense Command">NORAD air sovereignty</a> patrols and participated in combat during the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bosnia" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosnia">Bosnia</a> crisis.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">Suez Crisis</a> of 1956, future Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Lester_B._Pearson" title="Lester B. Pearson">Lester B. Pearson</a> eased tensions by proposing the inception of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_peacekeeping" title="United Nations peacekeeping">United Nations Peacekeeping Force</a>, for which he was awarded the 1957 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[216]</a></sup> As this was the first UN peacekeeping mission, Pearson is often credited as the inventor of the concept.<sup id="cite_ref-Mays2010_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mays2010-218">[217]</a></sup> Canada has since served in over 50 peacekeeping missions, including every UN peacekeeping effort until 1989,<sup id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup> and has since maintained forces in international missions in <a href="/wiki/Rwanda" title="Rwanda">Rwanda</a>, the former <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavia" title="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>, and elsewhere; Canada has sometimes faced controversy over its involvement in foreign countries, notably in the 1993 <a href="/wiki/Somalia_affair" title="Somalia affair">Somalia affair</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[218]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2001, Canada <a href="/wiki/Canada_in_the_War_in_Afghanistan" title="Canada in the War in Afghanistan">deployed troops to Afghanistan</a> as part of the U.S. stabilization force and the UN-authorized, NATO-led <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">International Security Assistance Force</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-KlassenAlbo2013_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KlassenAlbo2013-220">[219]</a></sup> In February 2007, Canada, Italy, the United Kingdom, Norway, and Russia announced their joint commitment to a $1.5-billion project to help develop vaccines for developing nations, and called on other countries to join them.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[220]</a></sup> In August 2007, Canada's <a href="/wiki/Territorial_claims_in_the_Arctic" title="Territorial claims in the Arctic">territorial claims in the Arctic</a> were challenged after a <a href="/wiki/Arktika_2007" title="Arktika 2007">Russian underwater expedition</a> to the <a href="/wiki/North_Pole" title="North Pole">North Pole</a>; Canada has considered that area to be sovereign territory since 1925.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[221]</a></sup> In September 2020, Canada joined the <a href="/wiki/Access_to_COVID-19_Tools_Accelerator" title="Access to COVID-19 Tools Accelerator">COVID-19 Vaccines Global Access</a> (<a href="/wiki/COVAX" title="COVAX">COVAX</a>) program, which aims to ensure equal access to a potential <a href="/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019" title="Coronavirus disease 2019">COVID-19</a> vaccine for all member countries and to help lower-income countries secure doses.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[222]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The nation employs a professional, volunteer military force of approximately 79,000 active personnel and 32,250 reserve personnel.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[223]</a></sup> The unified <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Forces" class="mw-redirect" title="Canadian Forces">Canadian Forces</a> (CF) comprise the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Army" title="Canadian Army">Canadian Army</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Navy" title="Royal Canadian Navy">Royal Canadian Navy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Air_Force" title="Royal Canadian Air Force">Royal Canadian Air Force</a>. In 2013, Canada's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditure" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by military expenditure">military expenditure</a> totalled approximately <span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$19&nbsp;billion</span>, or around one&nbsp;percent of the country's GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[225]</a></sup> Following the 2016 Defense Policy Review, called "Strong, Secure, Engaged", the Canadian government announced a 70&nbsp;percent increase to the country's defence budget over the next decade.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[226]</a></sup> The Canadian Forces will acquire 88 fighter planes and 15 naval surface combatants based on the <a href="/wiki/Type_26_frigate" title="Type 26 frigate">Type 26 frigate</a> design, the latter as part of the <a href="/wiki/National_Shipbuilding_Procurement_Strategy" title="National Shipbuilding Procurement Strategy">National Shipbuilding Procurement Strategy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[228]</a></sup> Canada's total military expenditure is expected to reach <span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$32.7&nbsp;billion</span> by 2027.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[229]</a></sup> Canada's military currently has over 3000 personnel <a href="/wiki/List_of_Canadian_military_operations" title="List of Canadian military operations">deployed</a> overseas, including in <a href="/wiki/Operation_Impact" title="Operation Impact">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Operation_Unifier" title="Operation Unifier">Ukraine</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Caribbe" title="Operation Caribbe">Caribbean Sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Provinces_and_territories">Provinces and territories</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada" title="Provinces and territories of Canada">Provinces and territories of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Canadian_federalism" title="Canadian federalism">Canadian federalism</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
        <a href="/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada" title="Provinces and territories of Canada"><img alt="Labelled map of Canada detailing its provinces and territories" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Political_map_of_Canada.svg/350px-Political_map_of_Canada.svg.png" decoding="async" width="350" height="285" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Political_map_of_Canada.svg/525px-Political_map_of_Canada.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Political_map_of_Canada.svg/700px-Political_map_of_Canada.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1130" data-file-height="920"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Political_map_of_Canada.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Political map of Canada showing its 10 provinces and 3 territories
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Canada is a federation composed of ten provinces and three <a href="/wiki/Territory_(administrative_division)" class="mw-redirect" title="Territory (administrative division)">territories</a>. In turn, these may be grouped into <a href="/wiki/List_of_regions_of_Canada" title="List of regions of Canada">four main regions</a>: <a href="/wiki/Western_Canada" title="Western Canada">Western Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Canada" title="Central Canada">Central Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Canada" title="Atlantic Canada">Atlantic Canada</a>, and Northern Canada (<i><a href="/wiki/Eastern_Canada" title="Eastern Canada">Eastern Canada</a></i> refers to Central Canada and Atlantic Canada together).<sup id="cite_ref-HamelKeil2015_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HamelKeil2015-232">[231]</a></sup> Provinces have more autonomy than territories, having responsibility for social programs such as <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="Health care in Canada">health care</a>, <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Canada" title="Education in Canada">education</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Social_programs_in_Canada" title="Social programs in Canada">welfare</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[232]</a></sup> Together, the provinces collect more revenue than the federal government, an almost unique structure among federations in the world. Using its spending powers, the federal government can initiate national policies in provincial areas, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Canada_Health_Act" title="Canada Health Act">Canada Health Act</a></i>; the provinces can opt out of these, but rarely do so in practice. <a href="/wiki/Equalization_payments" title="Equalization payments">Equalization payments</a> are made by the federal government to ensure reasonably uniform standards of services and taxation are kept between the richer and poorer provinces.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[233]</a></sup> The major difference between a Canadian province and a territory is that provinces receive their power and authority from the <i>Constitution Act, 1867</i>, whereas territorial governments have powers delegated to them by the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Canada" title="Parliament of Canada">Parliament of Canada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-OliverMacklem2017a_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OliverMacklem2017a-235">[234]</a></sup> The powers flowing from the <i>Constitution Act, 1867</i> are divided between the Government of Canada (the federal government) and the provincial governments to exercise exclusively.<sup id="cite_ref-Meligrana2004_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meligrana2004-236">[235]</a></sup> A change to the division of powers between the federal government and the provinces requires a <a href="/wiki/Amendments_to_the_Constitution_of_Canada" title="Amendments to the Constitution of Canada">constitutional amendment</a>, whereas a similar change affecting the territories can be performed unilaterally by the Parliament of Canada or government.<sup id="cite_ref-Nicholson1979_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nicholson1979-237">[236]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Canada" title="Economy of Canada">Economy of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_companies_of_Canada" title="List of companies of Canada">List of companies of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Canada is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">tenth-largest economy</a> as of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, with a <a href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a> of approximately US$1.73&nbsp;trillion.<sup id="cite_ref-GDP_IMF_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GDP_IMF-238">[237]</a></sup> It is one of the <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">least corrupt countries in the world</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-RotbergCarment2018_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RotbergCarment2018-239">[238]</a></sup> and is one of the world's top ten <a href="/wiki/Trading_nation" title="Trading nation">trading nations</a>, with a highly <a href="/wiki/Globalized" class="mw-redirect" title="Globalized">globalized</a> economy.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[239]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[240]</a></sup> Canada has a <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> ranking above the U.S. and most western European nations on <a href="/wiki/The_Heritage_Foundation" title="The Heritage Foundation">The Heritage Foundation</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Economic_Freedom" title="Index of Economic Freedom">Index of Economic Freedom</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[241]</a></sup> and experiencing a relatively low level of <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">income disparity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[242]</a></sup> The country's average household <a href="/wiki/Disposable_income" class="mw-redirect" title="Disposable income">disposable income</a> per capita is "well above" the OECD average.<sup id="cite_ref-OECDBLI_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDBLI-244">[243]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Toronto_Stock_Exchange" title="Toronto Stock Exchange">Toronto Stock Exchange</a> is the ninth-largest <a href="/wiki/Stock_exchange" title="Stock exchange">stock exchange</a> in the world by <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a>, listing over 1,500 companies with a combined market capitalization of over US$2&nbsp;trillion.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[244]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2018, Canadian trade in goods and services reached <span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$1.5</span>&nbsp;trillion.<sup id="cite_ref-econ_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-econ-246">[245]</a></sup> Canada's exports totalled over <span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$585</span>&nbsp;billion, while its imported goods were worth over <span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$607</span>&nbsp;billion, of which approximately <span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$391</span>&nbsp;billion originated from the United States, <span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$216</span>&nbsp;billion from non-U.S. sources.<sup id="cite_ref-econ_246-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-econ-246">[245]</a></sup> In 2018, Canada had a <a href="/wiki/Trade_deficit" class="mw-redirect" title="Trade deficit">trade deficit</a> in goods of <span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$22</span>&nbsp;billion and a trade deficit in services of <span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$25</span>&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-econ_246-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-econ-246">[245]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since the early 20th century, the growth of Canada's manufacturing, mining, and service sectors has transformed the nation from a largely rural economy to an urbanized, industrial one.<sup id="cite_ref-HarrisMatthews1987l_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HarrisMatthews1987l-247">[246]</a></sup> Like many other <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed countries</a>, the Canadian economy is dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service industry</a>, which employs about three-quarters of the country's workforce.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[247]</a></sup> However, Canada is unusual among developed countries in the importance of its <a href="/wiki/Primary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Primary sector of the economy">primary sector</a>, in which the <a href="/wiki/Forestry_in_Canada" title="Forestry in Canada">forestry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Petroleum_production_in_Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="Petroleum production in Canada">petroleum industries</a> are two of the most prominent components.<sup id="cite_ref-SueyoshiGoto2018_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SueyoshiGoto2018-249">[248]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Toronto_(15085972212).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Toronto_%2815085972212%29.jpg/240px-Toronto_%2815085972212%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Toronto_%2815085972212%29.jpg/360px-Toronto_%2815085972212%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Toronto_%2815085972212%29.jpg/480px-Toronto_%2815085972212%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Toronto_(15085972212).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Financial_District,_Toronto" title="Financial District, Toronto">Toronto financial district</a> is the second largest financial centre in North America, the seventh largest globally in employment and the heart of Canada's finance industry.<sup id="cite_ref-Sassen2018_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sassen2018-250">[249]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Canada's economic integration with the United States has increased significantly since <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[250]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Automotive_Products_Trade_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="Automotive Products Trade Agreement">Automotive Products Trade Agreement</a> of 1965 opened Canada's borders to trade in the automobile manufacturing industry.<sup id="cite_ref-KerrPerdikis2014_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KerrPerdikis2014-252">[251]</a></sup> In the 1970s, concerns over energy self-sufficiency and foreign ownership in the manufacturing sectors prompted Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Trudeau" title="Pierre Trudeau">Pierre Trudeau</a>'s Liberal government to enact the <a href="/wiki/National_Energy_Program" title="National Energy Program">National Energy Program</a> (NEP) and the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Investment_Review_Agency" title="Foreign Investment Review Agency">Foreign Investment Review Agency</a> (FIRA).<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[252]</a></sup> In the 1980s, Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Brian_Mulroney" title="Brian Mulroney">Brian Mulroney</a>'s Progressive Conservatives abolished the NEP and changed the name of FIRA to <a href="/wiki/Invest_in_Canada" title="Invest in Canada">Investment Canada</a>, to encourage foreign investment.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[253]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Canada_%E2%80%93_United_States_Free_Trade_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="Canada – United States Free Trade Agreement">Canada&nbsp;– United States Free Trade Agreement</a> (FTA) of 1988 eliminated tariffs between the two countries, while the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">North American Free Trade Agreement</a> (NAFTA) expanded the free-trade zone to include <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a> in 1994 (later replaced by the <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement" title="United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement">Canada–United States–Mexico Agreement</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Nzongola-NtalajaKrieger2001_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nzongola-NtalajaKrieger2001-255">[254]</a></sup> Canada has a strong <a href="/wiki/Cooperative_banking" title="Cooperative banking">cooperative banking</a> sector, with the world's highest per-capita membership in <a href="/wiki/Credit_union" title="Credit union">credit unions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-KobrakMartin2018_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KobrakMartin2018-256">[255]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada is one of the few developed nations that are net exporters of energy.<sup id="cite_ref-SueyoshiGoto2018_249-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SueyoshiGoto2018-249">[248]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-energy_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-energy-257">[256]</a></sup> Atlantic Canada possesses vast <a href="/wiki/Offshore_drilling" title="Offshore drilling">offshore</a> deposits of natural gas, and Alberta also hosts large oil and gas resources. The vastness of the <a href="/wiki/Athabasca_oil_sands" title="Athabasca oil sands">Athabasca oil sands</a> and other assets results in Canada having a 13&nbsp;percent share of global <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves" title="Oil reserves">oil reserves</a>, comprising the world's third-largest share after <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves_in_Venezuela" title="Oil reserves in Venezuela">Venezuela</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Oil reserves in Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lopez-Vallejo2016_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lopez-Vallejo2016-258">[257]</a></sup> Canada is additionally one of the world's largest suppliers of agricultural products; the Canadian Prairies are one of the most important global producers of wheat, <a href="/wiki/Canola" class="mw-redirect" title="Canola">canola</a>, and other grains.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[258]</a></sup> The federal <a href="/wiki/Natural_Resources_Canada" title="Natural Resources Canada">Department of Natural Resources</a> provides statistics regarding its major exports; the country is a leading exporter of <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nickel" title="Nickel">nickel</a>, <a href="/wiki/PGMs" class="mw-redirect" title="PGMs">platinoids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aluminum" class="mw-redirect" title="Aluminum">aluminum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">iron ore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coking_coal" class="mw-redirect" title="Coking coal">coking coal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">lead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Molybdenum" title="Molybdenum">molybdenum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cobalt" title="Cobalt">cobalt</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cadmium" title="Cadmium">cadmium</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Haldar2016_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haldar2016-260">[259]</a></sup> Many towns in northern Canada, where agriculture is difficult, are sustainable because of nearby mines or sources of timber. Canada also has a sizeable manufacturing sector centred in southern Ontario and Quebec, with automobiles and <a href="/wiki/Aeronautics" title="Aeronautics">aeronautics</a> representing particularly important industries.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[260]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Canada" title="Science and technology in Canada">Science and technology in Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:STS-116_Payload_(NASA_S116-E-05364).jpg" class="image"><img alt="A Space Shuttle in space, with Earth in the background. A mechanical arm labelled &quot;Canada&quot; rises from the Shuttle." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/STS-116_Payload_%28NASA_S116-E-05364%29.jpg/220px-STS-116_Payload_%28NASA_S116-E-05364%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/STS-116_Payload_%28NASA_S116-E-05364%29.jpg/330px-STS-116_Payload_%28NASA_S116-E-05364%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/STS-116_Payload_%28NASA_S116-E-05364%29.jpg/440px-STS-116_Payload_%28NASA_S116-E-05364%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2836" data-file-height="1876"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:STS-116_Payload_(NASA_S116-E-05364).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Canadarm" title="Canadarm">Canadarm</a> robotic manipulator in action on <span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle" title="Space Shuttle">Space Shuttle</a></span> <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle_Discovery" title="Space Shuttle Discovery"><i>Discovery</i></a> during the <a href="/wiki/STS-116" title="STS-116">STS-116</a> mission in 2006
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2018, Canada spent approximately <span style="white-space: nowrap">CA$34.5&nbsp;billion</span> on domestic <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a>, of which around $7&nbsp;billion was provided by the federal and provincial governments.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[261]</a></sup> As of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country has produced fifteen <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country" title="List of Nobel laureates by country">Nobel laureates</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">physics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">chemistry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Medicine" class="mw-redirect" title="Nobel Prize in Medicine">medicine</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[262]</a></sup> and was ranked fourth worldwide for scientific research quality in a major 2012 survey of international scientists.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[263]</a></sup> It is furthermore home to the headquarters of a number of global technology firms.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[264]</a></sup> Canada <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users" title="List of countries by number of Internet users">has one of the highest levels of Internet access in the world</a>, with over 33&nbsp;million users, equivalent to around 94 percent of its total 2014 population.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[265]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Some of the most notable scientific developments in Canada include the creation of the modern <a href="/wiki/Alkaline_battery" title="Alkaline battery">alkaline battery</a><sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[266]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Polio_vaccine" title="Polio vaccine">polio vaccine</a><sup id="cite_ref-Farrell_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Farrell-268">[267]</a></sup> and discoveries about the interior structure of the <a href="/wiki/Atomic_nucleus" title="Atomic nucleus">atomic nucleus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Katz_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Katz-269">[268]</a></sup> Other major Canadian scientific contributions include the <a href="/wiki/Artificial_cardiac_pacemaker" title="Artificial cardiac pacemaker">artificial cardiac pacemaker</a>, mapping the <a href="/wiki/Visual_cortex" title="Visual cortex">visual cortex</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[269]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-topten_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-topten-271">[270]</a></sup> the development of the <a href="/wiki/Electron_microscope" title="Electron microscope">electron microscope</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[271]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[272]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">plate tectonics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deep_learning" title="Deep learning">deep learning</a>, <a href="/wiki/Multi-touch" title="Multi-touch">multi-touch</a> technology and the identification of the first <a href="/wiki/Black_hole" title="Black hole">black hole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cygnus_X-1" title="Cygnus X-1">Cygnus X-1</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[273]</a></sup> Canada has a long history of discovery in genetics, which include <a href="/wiki/Stem_cell" title="Stem cell">stem cells</a>, <a href="/wiki/Site-directed_mutagenesis" title="Site-directed mutagenesis">site-directed mutagenesis</a>, <a href="/wiki/T-cell_receptor" title="T-cell receptor">T-cell receptor</a> and the identification of the genes that cause <a href="/wiki/Fanconi_anemia" title="Fanconi anemia">Fanconi anemia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cystic_fibrosis" title="Cystic fibrosis">cystic fibrosis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Early-onset_Alzheimer%27s_disease" title="Early-onset Alzheimer's disease">early-onset Alzheimer's disease</a>, among numerous other diseases.<sup id="cite_ref-topten_271-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-topten-271">[270]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[274]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Space_Agency" title="Canadian Space Agency">Canadian Space Agency</a> operates a highly active space program, conducting deep-space, planetary, and aviation research, and developing rockets and satellites.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[275]</a></sup> Canada was the third country to design and construct a satellite after the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_space_program" title="Soviet space program">Soviet Union</a> and the United States, with the 1962 <a href="/wiki/Alouette_1" title="Alouette 1">Alouette 1</a> launch.<sup id="cite_ref-Angelo2009s_277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Angelo2009s-277">[276]</a></sup> Canada is a participant in the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a> (ISS), and is a pioneer in space robotics, having constructed the <a href="/wiki/Canadarm" title="Canadarm">Canadarm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canadarm2" class="mw-redirect" title="Canadarm2">Canadarm2</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dextre" title="Dextre">Dextre</a> robotic manipulators for the ISS and NASA's <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle" title="Space Shuttle">Space Shuttle</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bidaud2012_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bidaud2012-278">[277]</a></sup> Since the 1960s, Canada's aerospace industry has designed and built numerous marques of satellite, including <a href="/wiki/Radarsat-1" title="Radarsat-1">Radarsat-1</a> and <a href="/wiki/Radarsat-2" title="Radarsat-2">2</a>, <a href="/wiki/ISIS_(satellite)" title="ISIS (satellite)">ISIS</a> and <a href="/wiki/Microvariability_and_Oscillations_of_STars_telescope" class="mw-redirect" title="Microvariability and Oscillations of STars telescope">MOST</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[278]</a></sup> Canada has also produced one of the world's most successful and widely used <a href="/wiki/Sounding_rocket" title="Sounding rocket">sounding rockets</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Black_Brant_(rocket)" title="Black Brant (rocket)">Black Brant</a>; over 1,000 Black Brants have been launched since the rocket's introduction in 1961.<sup id="cite_ref-Godefroy2017_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Godefroy2017-280">[279]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Canada" title="Demographics of Canada">Demographics of Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Canada" title="List of cities in Canada">List of cities in Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg" class="image"><img alt="Two-colour map of Windsor area with towns along the St. Lawrence river" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg/220px-Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg/330px-Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg/440px-Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="400"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Quebec_City%E2%80%93Windsor_Corridor" title="Quebec City–Windsor Corridor">Quebec City–Windsor Corridor</a> is the most densely populated and heavily industrialized region of Canada, spanning 1,200&nbsp;km (750&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-McMurryShepherd2004_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McMurryShepherd2004-281">[280]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/2016_Canadian_Census" class="mw-redirect" title="2016 Canadian Census">2016 Canadian Census</a> enumerated a <a href="/wiki/Population_of_Canada_by_year" class="mw-redirect" title="Population of Canada by year">total population</a> of 35,151,728, an increase of around 5.0 percent over the 2011 figure.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[281]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[282]</a></sup> Between 2011 and May 2016, Canada's population grew by 1.7&nbsp;million people, with immigrants accounting for two-thirds of the increase.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[283]</a></sup> Between 1990 and 2008, the population increased by 5.6&nbsp;million, equivalent to 20.4 percent overall growth.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[284]</a></sup> The main drivers of population growth are <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Canada" title="Immigration to Canada">immigration</a> and, to a lesser extent, natural growth.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[285]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada has one of the highest per-capita immigration rates in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[286]</a></sup> driven mainly by <a href="/wiki/Economic_impact_of_immigration_to_Canada" title="Economic impact of immigration to Canada">economic policy</a> and also <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Canada#Immigration_categories" title="Immigration to Canada">family reunification</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-HollifieldMartin2014_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HollifieldMartin2014-288">[287]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BeaujotKerr2007j_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BeaujotKerr2007j-289">[288]</a></sup> The Canadian public, as well as the major political parties, support the current level of immigration.<sup id="cite_ref-HollifieldMartin2014_288-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HollifieldMartin2014-288">[287]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FreemanHansen2013_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FreemanHansen2013-290">[289]</a></sup> In 2019, a total of 341,180 immigrants were admitted to Canada, mainly from Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[290]</a></sup> India, Philippines and China are the top three countries of origin for immigrants moving to Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[291]</a></sup> New immigrants settle mostly in major <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_100_largest_population_centres_in_Canada" title="List of the 100 largest population centres in Canada">urban areas</a> such as Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[292]</a></sup> Canada also accepts large numbers of <a href="/wiki/Third_country_resettlement" title="Third country resettlement">refugees</a>, accounting for over 10 percent of annual global <a href="/wiki/Third_country_resettlement" title="Third country resettlement">refugee resettlements</a>; it resettled more than 28,000 in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[293]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[294]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada's population density, at 3.7 inhabitants per square kilometre (9.6/sq&nbsp;mi), is among the lowest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[295]</a></sup> Canada spans latitudinally from the 83rd parallel north to the 41st parallel north, and approximately 95&nbsp;percent of the population is found south of the 55th parallel north.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD2014_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD2014-297">[296]</a></sup> About four-fifths of the population lives within 150 kilometres (93&nbsp;mi) of the border with the contiguous United States.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[297]</a></sup> The most densely populated part of the country, accounting for nearly 50 percent, is the <a href="/wiki/Quebec_City%E2%80%93Windsor_Corridor" title="Quebec City–Windsor Corridor">Quebec City–Windsor Corridor</a> in Southern Quebec and Southern Ontario along the Great Lakes and the Saint Lawrence River.<sup id="cite_ref-McMurryShepherd2004_281-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McMurryShepherd2004-281">[280]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-OECD2014_297-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD2014-297">[296]</a></sup> An additional 30 percent live along the British Columbia <a href="/wiki/Lower_Mainland" title="Lower Mainland">Lower Mainland</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Calgary%E2%80%93Edmonton_Corridor" title="Calgary–Edmonton Corridor">Calgary–Edmonton Corridor</a> in Alberta.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[298]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The majority of Canadians (67.7&nbsp;percent) live in family households, 28.2&nbsp;percent report living alone, and those living with unrelated persons reported at 4.1&nbsp;percent.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-300">[299]</a></sup> 6.3 percent of households are multigenerational with 34.7 percent of young adults aged 20 to 34 living with their parents.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_300-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-300">[299]</a></sup> 69.0 percent of households own their dwellings with 58.6 percent of those homes having an ongoing mortgage.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[300]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="infobox" style="text-align:center; width:95%; font-size:90%"> 
       <tbody>
