      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Canada" title="Healthcare in Canada">Healthcare in Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Healthcare in Canada is delivered through the provincial and territorial systems of <a href="/wiki/Publicly_funded_health_care" title="Publicly funded health care">publicly funded health care</a>, informally called Medicare.<sup id="cite_ref-AaseWaring2017_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AaseWaring2017-303">[302]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[303]</a></sup> It is guided by the provisions of the <i><a href="/wiki/Canada_Health_Act" title="Canada Health Act">Canada Health Act</a></i> of 1984,<sup id="cite_ref-Bégin1988_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bégin1988-305">[304]</a></sup> and is <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-LeattMapa2003_306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LeattMapa2003-306">[305]</a></sup> Universal access to publicly funded health services "is often considered by Canadians as a fundamental value that ensures national health care insurance for everyone wherever they live in the country."<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[306]</a></sup> However, 30&nbsp;percent of Canadians' healthcare is paid for through the private sector.<sup id="cite_ref-Kroll2012_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kroll2012-308">[307]</a></sup> This mostly goes towards services not covered or partially covered by Medicare, such as <a href="/wiki/Prescription_drug" title="Prescription drug">prescription drugs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dentistry" title="Dentistry">dentistry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Optometry" title="Optometry">optometry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kroll2012_308-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kroll2012-308">[307]</a></sup> Approximately 65 to 75&nbsp;percent of Canadians have some form of supplementary health insurance related to the aforementioned reasons; many receive it through their employers or utilizes secondary social service programs related to extended coverage for families receiving social assistance or vulnerable demographics, such as seniors, minors, and those with disabilities.<sup id="cite_ref-Chen2018_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chen2018-309">[308]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kroll2012_308-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kroll2012-308">[307]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Health_care_cost_rise.svg" class="image"><img alt="graph of expenditures as described in caption" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Health_care_cost_rise.svg/290px-Health_care_cost_rise.svg.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Health_care_cost_rise.svg/435px-Health_care_cost_rise.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Health_care_cost_rise.svg/580px-Health_care_cost_rise.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="440"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Health_care_cost_rise.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Health care cost rise based on total expenditure on health as percent of GDP. Countries shown are the United States, Germany, Austria, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, and Canada.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In common with many other developed countries, Canada is experiencing a cost increase due to a <a href="/wiki/Demographic_transition" title="Demographic transition">demographic shift</a> towards an older population, with more retirees and fewer people of working age. In 2006, the average age was 39.5 years;<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[309]</a></sup> within twelve years it had risen to 42.4 years,<sup id="cite_ref-cia_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-311">[310]</a></sup> with a life expectancy of 81.1 years.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[311]</a></sup> A 2016 report by the <a href="/wiki/Chief_public_health_officer_of_Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="Chief public health officer of Canada">chief public health officer of Canada</a> found that 88&nbsp;percent of Canadians, one of the highest proportions of the population among G7 countries, indicated that they "had good or very good health".<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[312]</a></sup> 80&nbsp;percent of Canadian adults self-report having at least one major risk factor for chronic disease: smoking, physical inactivity, unhealthy eating or excessive alcohol use.<sup id="cite_ref-GregoryStephens2019_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GregoryStephens2019-314">[313]</a></sup> Canada has one of the highest rates of adult obesity among Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (<a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>) countries attributing to approximately 2.7&nbsp;million cases of <a href="/wiki/Diabetes" title="Diabetes">diabetes</a> (types 1 and 2 combined).<sup id="cite_ref-GregoryStephens2019_314-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GregoryStephens2019-314">[313]</a></sup> Four chronic diseases—<a href="/wiki/Cancer" title="Cancer">cancer</a> (leading cause of death), <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_diseases" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardiovascular diseases">cardiovascular diseases</a>, <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_diseases" class="mw-redirect" title="Respiratory diseases">respiratory diseases</a> and diabetes—account for 65&nbsp;percent of deaths in Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[314]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[315]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2017, the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Institute_for_Health_Information" title="Canadian Institute for Health Information">Canadian Institute for Health Information</a> reported that healthcare spending reached $242<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>billion, or 11.5&nbsp;percent of Canada's <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> (GDP) for that year.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[316]</a></sup> Canada's per-capita spending ranks as seventh on the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_health_expenditure_per_capita" title="List of countries by total health expenditure per capita">list of countries by total health expenditure per capita</a> in the OECD and above the average of 8.8&nbsp;percent of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-OECDstats_318-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDstats-318">[317]</a></sup> Canada has performed close to, or above the average on the majority of OECD health indicators since the early 2000s.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[318]</a></sup> In 2017 Canada ranked above the average on OECD indicators for wait-times and access to care, with average scores for quality of care and use of resources.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[319]</a></sup> A comprehensive study from 2017 of the top 11 countries ranked Canada's health care system third-to-last.<sup id="cite_ref-urlCanadathird-last_321-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-urlCanadathird-last-321">[320]</a></sup> Identified weaknesses of Canada's system were comparatively higher infant mortality rate, the prevalence of chronic conditions, long wait times, poor availability of after-hours care, and a lack of prescription drugs and dental coverage.<sup id="cite_ref-urlCanadathird-last_321-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-urlCanadathird-last-321">[320]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Canada" title="Education in Canada">Education in Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Canada" title="Higher education in Canada">Higher education in Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:14th_G7_summit.jpg" class="image"><img alt="portrait of the group of named world leaders" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/14th_G7_summit.jpg/220px-14th_G7_summit.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="171" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/14th_G7_summit.jpg/330px-14th_G7_summit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/14th_G7_summit.jpg/440px-14th_G7_summit.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2988" data-file-height="2316"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:14th_G7_summit.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/14th_G7_summit" title="14th G7 summit">14th G7 summit</a> leaders at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Toronto" title="University of Toronto">University of Toronto</a>: (left to right) <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Delors" title="Jacques Delors">Jacques Delors</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ciriaco_De_Mita" title="Ciriaco De Mita">Ciriaco De Mita</a>, <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher" title="Margaret Thatcher">Margaret Thatcher</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brian_Mulroney" title="Brian Mulroney">Brian Mulroney</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Mitterrand" title="François Mitterrand">François Mitterrand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Helmut_Kohl" title="Helmut Kohl">Helmut Kohl</a> and <a href="/wiki/Noboru_Takeshita" title="Noboru Takeshita">Noboru Takeshita</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Education_in_Canada" title="Education in Canada">Education in Canada</a> is for the most part provided <a href="/wiki/Public_education" class="mw-redirect" title="Public education">publicly</a>, funded and overseen by <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Canada" title="Government of Canada">federal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="Provinces of Canada">provincial</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Local_government" title="Local government">local governments</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2015_federal_budget_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015_federal_budget-322">[321]</a></sup> Education is within provincial jurisdiction and the curriculum is overseen by the province.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[322]</a></sup> Education in Canada is generally divided into <a href="/wiki/Primary_education" title="Primary education">primary education</a>, followed by secondary education and post-secondary. Education in both English and French is available in most places across Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-Epstein2008_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Epstein2008-324">[323]</a></sup> Canadian provinces and territories are responsible for education provision.<sup id="cite_ref-MontesinosVela2013_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MontesinosVela2013-325">[324]</a></sup> Canada has a large number of Universities, almost all of which are publicly funded.<sup id="cite_ref-ShanahanNilson2016_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ShanahanNilson2016-326">[325]</a></sup> Established in 1663, <a href="/wiki/Universit%C3%A9_Laval" title="Université Laval">Université Laval</a> is the oldest post-secondary <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Canada" title="Higher education in Canada">institution in Canada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BlakeKeshen2017p249_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BlakeKeshen2017p249-327">[326]</a></sup> The largest University is the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Toronto" title="University of Toronto">University of Toronto</a> with over 85,000 students.<sup id="cite_ref-Richards2019_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Richards2019-328">[327]</a></sup> Four Universities are regularly ranked among the top 100 world-wide, namely University of Toronto, <a href="/wiki/University_of_British_Columbia" title="University of British Columbia">University of British Columbia</a>, <a href="/wiki/McGill_University" title="McGill University">McGill University</a> and <a href="/wiki/McMaster_University" title="McMaster University">McMaster University</a>, with a total of 18 <a href="/wiki/Rankings_of_universities_in_Canada" title="Rankings of universities in Canada">Universities ranked</a> in the top 500 worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-ARWU2019_|_Canada_Universities_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ARWU2019_|_Canada_Universities-329">[328]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to a 2019 report by the OECD, Canada is one of the most educated countries in the world;<sup id="cite_ref-world_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world-330">[329]</a></sup> the country ranks first worldwide in the number of adults having <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary education</a>, with over 56 percent of Canadian adults having attained at least an undergraduate college or university degree.<sup id="cite_ref-world_330-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world-330">[329]</a></sup> Canada spends about 5.3&nbsp;percent of its GDP on education.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[330]</a></sup> The country invests heavily in tertiary education (more than US$20,000 per student).<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[331]</a></sup> As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 89 percent of adults aged 25 to 64 have earned the equivalent of a high-school degree, compared to an OECD average of 75 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-OECDBLI2_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDBLI2-333">[332]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education" title="Compulsory education">mandatory education</a> age ranges between 5–7 to 16–18 years,<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[333]</a></sup> contributing to an adult literacy rate of 99 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_311-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-311">[310]</a></sup> Just over 60,000 children are <a href="/wiki/Homeschooling_in_Canada" title="Homeschooling in Canada">homeschooled</a> as of 2016. In 2002, 43 percent of Canadians aged 25 to 64 possessed a post-secondary education; for those aged 25 to 34, the rate of post-secondary education reached 51 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[334]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a> indicates Canadian students perform well above the OECD average, particularly in mathematics, science, and reading,<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[335]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[336]</a></sup> ranking the overall knowledge and skills of Canadian 15-year-olds as the sixth-best in the world. Canada is a well-performing OECD country in reading literacy, mathematics, and science with the average student scoring 523.7, compared with the OECD average of 493 in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[337]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[338]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnicity">Ethnicity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Canadians" title="Canadians">Canadians</a>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the 2016 Canadian Census, the country's largest <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_origins_of_people_in_Canada" title="Ethnic origins of people in Canada">self-reported ethnic origin</a> is Canadian (accounting for 32&nbsp;percent of the population),<sup id="cite_ref-Canadian_342-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Canadian-342">[b]</a></sup> followed by <a href="/wiki/English_Canadian" class="mw-redirect" title="English Canadian">English</a> (18.3 percent), <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Canadian" class="mw-redirect" title="Scottish Canadian">Scottish</a> (13.9 percent), French (13.6 percent), <a href="/wiki/Irish_Canadian" class="mw-redirect" title="Irish Canadian">Irish</a> (13.4 percent), <a href="/wiki/Canadians_of_German_ethnicity" class="mw-redirect" title="Canadians of German ethnicity">German</a> (9.6 percent), <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Canadian" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese Canadian">Chinese</a> (5.1 percent), <a href="/wiki/Italian_Canadians" title="Italian Canadians">Italian</a> (4.6 percent), First Nations (4.4 percent), <a href="/wiki/Indo-Canadians" title="Indo-Canadians">Indian</a> (4.0 percent), and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Canadian" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian Canadian">Ukrainian</a> (3.9 percent).<sup id="cite_ref-ethnicity_343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicity-343">[341]</a></sup> There are 600 recognized <a href="/wiki/List_of_First_Nations_peoples" title="List of First Nations peoples">First Nations governments or bands</a>, encompassing a total of 1,525,565 people.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[342]</a></sup> The Indigenous population in Canada is growing at almost twice the national rate, and four percent of Canada's population claimed an Indigenous identity in 2006. Another 22.3 percent of the population belonged to a non-Indigenous <a href="/wiki/Visible_minority" title="Visible minority">visible minority</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Census_Profile,_2016_Census_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census_Profile,_2016_Census-345">[343]</a></sup> In 2016, the largest visible minority groups were <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Canadian" class="mw-redirect" title="South Asian Canadian">South Asian</a> (5.6 percent), Chinese (5.1 percent) and <a href="/wiki/Black_Canadians" title="Black Canadians">Black</a> (3.5 percent).<sup id="cite_ref-Census_Profile,_2016_Census_345-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census_Profile,_2016_Census-345">[343]</a></sup> Between 2011 and 2016, the visible minority population rose by 18.4 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-Census_Profile,_2016_Census_345-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census_Profile,_2016_Census-345">[343]</a></sup> In 1961, less than two percent of Canada's population (about 300,000 people) were members of visible minority groups.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[344]</a></sup> Indigenous peoples are not considered a visible minority in Statistics Canada calculations.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[345]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Canada" title="Languages of Canada">Languages of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg" class="image"><img alt="Map of Canada with English speakers and French speakers at a percentage" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg/220px-Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="188" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg/330px-Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg/440px-Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1100" data-file-height="940"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Approximately 98&nbsp;percent of Canadians can speak either or both English and French:<sup id="cite_ref-Highlights_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Highlights-348">[346]</a></sup><small><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
          <div class="legend">
           <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#FFE400; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;English – 56.9%
          </div>
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
          <div class="legend">
           <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#D8A820; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;English and French – 16.1%
          </div>
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
          <div class="legend">
           <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#B07400; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;French – 21.3%
          </div>
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
          <div class="legend">
           <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#F5F5DC; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Sparsely populated area ( &lt; 0.4 persons per km<sup>2</sup>)
          </div></small>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A multitude of languages are used by Canadians, with <a href="/wiki/Canadian_English" title="Canadian English">English</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canadian_French" title="Canadian French">French</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official languages</a>) being the <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">mother tongues</a> of approximately 56&nbsp;percent and 21&nbsp;percent of Canadians, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-Highlightsb_349-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Highlightsb-349">[347]</a></sup> As of the 2016 Census, just over 7.3&nbsp;million Canadians listed a non-official language as their mother tongue. Some of the most common non-official first languages include Chinese (1,227,680 first-language speakers), <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_language" title="Punjabi language">Punjabi</a> (501,680), Spanish (458,850), <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">Tagalog</a> (431,385), <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> (419,895), German (384,040), and Italian (375,645).<sup id="cite_ref-Highlightsb_349-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Highlightsb-349">[347]</a></sup> Canada's federal government practices <a href="/wiki/Official_bilingualism_in_Canada" title="Official bilingualism in Canada">official bilingualism</a>, which is applied by the <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_Commissioner_of_Official_Languages" title="Office of the Commissioner of Official Languages">commissioner of Official Languages</a> in consonance with <a href="/wiki/Section_16_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms" title="Section 16 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms">Section 16 of the <i>Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms</i></a> and the federal <i><a href="/wiki/Official_Languages_Act_(Canada)" title="Official Languages Act (Canada)">Official Languages Act</a></i>. English and French have equal status in federal courts, parliament, and in all federal institutions. Citizens have the right, where there is sufficient demand, to receive federal government services in either English or French and official-<a href="/wiki/Minority_language" title="Minority language">language minorities</a> are guaranteed their own schools in all provinces and territories.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[348]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The 1977 <i><a href="/wiki/Charter_of_the_French_Language" title="Charter of the French Language">Charter of the French Language</a></i> established French as the official language of Quebec.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[349]</a></sup> Although more than 85 percent of French-speaking Canadians live in Quebec, there are substantial <a href="/wiki/Francophone" class="mw-redirect" title="Francophone">Francophone</a> populations in <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_New_Brunswick" title="Demographics of New Brunswick">New Brunswick</a>, <a href="/wiki/Franco-Albertan" class="mw-redirect" title="Franco-Albertan">Alberta</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Franco-Manitoban" title="Franco-Manitoban">Manitoba</a>; <a href="/wiki/Franco-Ontarian" title="Franco-Ontarian">Ontario</a> has the largest French-speaking population outside Quebec.<sup id="cite_ref-Webber2015_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Webber2015-352">[350]</a></sup> New Brunswick, the only officially bilingual province, has a French-speaking Acadian minority constituting 33 percent of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-Auer2010b_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Auer2010b-353">[351]</a></sup> There are also clusters of Acadians in southwestern Nova Scotia, on Cape Breton Island, and through central and western Prince Edward Island.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[352]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other provinces have no official languages as such, but French is used as a language of instruction, in courts, and for other government services, in addition to English. Manitoba, Ontario, and Quebec allow for both English and French to be spoken in the provincial legislatures, and laws are enacted in both languages. In Ontario, French has some legal status, but is not fully co-official.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[353]</a></sup> There are 11 <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Canada#Aboriginal_languages" title="Languages of Canada">Indigenous language groups</a>, composed of more than 65 distinct languages and dialects.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[354]</a></sup> Several Indigenous languages have official status in the Northwest Territories.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[355]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Inuktitut" title="Inuktitut">Inuktitut</a> is the majority language in Nunavut, and is one of three official languages in the territory.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[356]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Additionally, Canada is home to many <a href="/wiki/Sign_language" title="Sign language">sign languages</a>, some of which are Indigenous.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[357]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/American_Sign_Language" title="American Sign Language">American Sign Language</a> (ASL) is spoken across the country due to the prevalence of ASL in primary and secondary schools.<sup id="cite_ref-JepsenClerck2015_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JepsenClerck2015-360">[358]</a></sup> Due to its historical relation to the francophone culture, <a href="/wiki/Quebec_Sign_Language" title="Quebec Sign Language">Quebec Sign Language</a> (LSQ) is spoken primarily in Quebec, although there are sizeable Francophone communities in New Brunswick, Ontario and Manitoba.<sup id="cite_ref-BaileyDolby2002_361-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BaileyDolby2002-361">[359]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Canada" title="Religion in Canada">Religion in Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Canada is religiously diverse, encompassing a wide range of beliefs and customs. Canada has no official church, and the government is officially committed to <a href="/wiki/Religious_pluralism" title="Religious pluralism">religious pluralism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Moon2008_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moon2008-362">[360]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Canada" title="Freedom of religion in Canada">Freedom of religion in Canada</a> is a constitutionally protected right, allowing individuals to assemble and worship without limitation or interference.<sup id="cite_ref-Scott2012n_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scott2012n-363">[361]</a></sup> The practice of religion is now generally considered a private matter throughout society and the state.<sup id="cite_ref-BoyleSheen2013_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoyleSheen2013-364">[362]</a></sup> With <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> in decline after having once been central and integral to Canadian culture and daily life,<sup id="cite_ref-Roberts2005w_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roberts2005w-365">[363]</a></sup> Canada has become a <a href="/wiki/Postchristianity" title="Postchristianity">post-Christian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Secularity" title="Secularity">secular</a> state.<sup id="cite_ref-BramadatSeljak2009_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BramadatSeljak2009-366">[364]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bowen2004_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bowen2004-367">[365]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-GregoryJohnston2009_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GregoryJohnston2009-368">[366]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BermanBhargava2013b_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BermanBhargava2013b-369">[367]</a></sup> The majority of Canadians consider <a href="/wiki/Importance_of_religion_by_country" title="Importance of religion by country">religion to be unimportant</a> in their daily lives,<sup id="cite_ref-Punnett2015a_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Punnett2015a-370">[368]</a></sup> but still believe in God.<sup id="cite_ref-Haskell2009_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haskell2009-371">[369]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the 2011 National Household Survey, 67.3&nbsp;percent of Canadians identify as Christian; of these, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholics</a> make up the largest group, accounting for 38.7&nbsp;percent of the population. Much of the remainder is made up of <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a>, who accounted for approximately 27&nbsp;percent in a 2011 survey.<sup id="cite_ref-2011NHSreligiondetailed_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011NHSreligiondetailed-372">[370]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[371]</a></sup> The largest Protestant <a href="/wiki/Christian_denomination" title="Christian denomination">denomination</a> is the <a href="/wiki/United_Church_of_Canada" title="United Church of Canada">United Church of Canada</a> (accounting for 6.1 percent of Canadians), followed by the <a href="/wiki/Anglican_Church_of_Canada" title="Anglican Church of Canada">Anglican Church of Canada</a> (5.0 percent), and <a href="/wiki/Baptists_in_Canada" title="Baptists in Canada">various Baptist sects</a> (1.9 percent).<sup id="cite_ref-statcan1_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-statcan1-3">[3]</a></sup> Secularization has been growing since the 1960s.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[372]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[373]</a></sup> In 2011, 23.9&nbsp;percent declared <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">no religious affiliation</a>, compared to 16.5&nbsp;percent in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[374]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Canada" title="Islam in Canada">Islam is the largest non-Christian religion in Canada</a>, constituting 3.2 percent of its population. It is also the fastest growing religion in Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-nationalpost1_377-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nationalpost1-377">[375]</a></sup> 1.5 percent of the <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Canada" title="Hinduism in Canada">Canadian population is Hindu</a> and 1.4 percent <a href="/wiki/Sikhism_in_Canada" title="Sikhism in Canada">is Sikh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-statcan1_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-statcan1-3">[3]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Canada" title="Culture of Canada">Culture of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg/170px-Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="187" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg/255px-Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg/340px-Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg 2x" data-file-width="702" data-file-height="771"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Monument to <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism_in_Canada" title="Multiculturalism in Canada">Multiculturalism</a>, by Francesco Pirelli in Toronto.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Canada's culture draws influences from its broad range of constituent nationalities, and policies that promote a "<a href="/wiki/Just_society" title="Just society">just society</a>" are constitutionally protected.<sup id="cite_ref-LaSelva1996k_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LaSelva1996k-378">[376]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[377]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Newman2012_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Newman2012-380">[378]</a></sup> Canada has placed emphasis on equality and inclusiveness for all its people.<sup id="cite_ref-GuoWong2015_381-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GuoWong2015-381">[379]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism_in_Canada" title="Multiculturalism in Canada">Multiculturalism</a> is often cited as one of Canada's significant accomplishments,<sup id="cite_ref-Sikka2014v_382-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sikka2014v-382">[380]</a></sup> and a key distinguishing element of Canadian identity.<sup id="cite_ref-JohnsonJoseph-Salisbury2018_383-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JohnsonJoseph-Salisbury2018-383">[381]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Caplow2001a_384-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Caplow2001a-384">[382]</a></sup> In Quebec, cultural identity is strong, and there is a <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Quebec" title="Culture of Quebec">French Canadian culture</a> that is distinct from English Canadian culture.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[383]</a></sup> However, as a whole, Canada is, in theory, a <a href="/wiki/Cultural_mosaic" title="Cultural mosaic">cultural mosaic</a>—a collection of regional ethnic subcultures.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[384]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada's approach to governance emphasizing multiculturalism, which is based on selective <a href="/wiki/Economic_migrant" title="Economic migrant">immigration</a>, <a href="/wiki/Social_integration" title="Social integration">social integration</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Suppression_of_dissent" class="mw-redirect" title="Suppression of dissent">suppression</a> of far-right politics, has wide public support.<sup id="cite_ref-Ambrosea_387-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ambrosea-387">[385]</a></sup> Government policies such as publicly funded health care, <a href="/wiki/Income_taxes_in_Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="Income taxes in Canada">higher taxation</a> to <a href="/wiki/Canadian_federal_budget" title="Canadian federal budget">redistribute wealth</a>, the outlawing of <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Canada" title="Capital punishment in Canada">capital punishment</a>, strong efforts to eliminate <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_Canada" title="Poverty in Canada">poverty</a>, strict <a href="/wiki/Gun_politics_in_Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="Gun politics in Canada">gun control</a>—alongside legislation with a <a href="/wiki/Social_liberal" class="mw-redirect" title="Social liberal">social liberal</a> attitude toward <a href="/wiki/Feminism_in_Canada" title="Feminism in Canada">women's rights</a> (like <a href="/wiki/Abortion_in_Canada" title="Abortion in Canada">pregnancy termination</a>), <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Canada" title="LGBT rights in Canada">LGBTQ rights</a>, <a href="/wiki/Euthanasia_in_Canada" title="Euthanasia in Canada">assisted euthanasia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cannabis_in_Canada" title="Cannabis in Canada">cannabis use</a>—are indicators of Canada's political and <a href="/wiki/Canadian_values" title="Canadian values">cultural values</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-HollifieldMartin2014b_388-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HollifieldMartin2014b-388">[386]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[387]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[388]</a></sup> Canadians also identify with the country's foreign aid policies, peacekeeping roles, the <a href="/wiki/National_Parks_of_Canada" title="National Parks of Canada">National park system</a> and the <i>Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-polls_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-polls-391">[389]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[390]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Historically, Canada has been influenced by <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Culture of the United Kingdom">British</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="French culture">French</a>, and Indigenous cultures and traditions. Through their language, <a href="/wiki/Native_American_art" class="mw-redirect" title="Native American art">art</a> and <a href="/wiki/First_Nations_music" class="mw-redirect" title="First Nations music">music</a>, Indigenous peoples continue to influence the Canadian identity.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[391]</a></sup> During the 20th century, Canadians with African, Caribbean and Asian nationalities have added to the Canadian identity and its culture.<sup id="cite_ref-TetteyPuplampu2005_394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TetteyPuplampu2005-394">[392]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Canadian_humour" title="Canadian humour">Canadian humour</a> is an integral part of the Canadian identity and is reflected in its <a href="/wiki/Canadian_folklore" title="Canadian folklore">folklore</a>, literature, music, art, and media. The primary characteristics of Canadian humour are irony, parody, and satire.<sup id="cite_ref-Nieguth2015_395-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nieguth2015-395">[393]</a></sup> Many <a href="/wiki/List_of_Canadian_comedians" title="List of Canadian comedians">Canadian comedians</a> have achieved international success in the American TV and film industries and are amongst the most recognized in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-LeeYork2016_396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LeeYork2016-396">[394]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada has a well-developed <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Canada" title="Media of Canada">media sector</a>, but its cultural output—particularly in <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Canada" title="Cinema of Canada">English films</a>, <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Canada" title="Television in Canada">television shows</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Canadian_magazines" title="List of Canadian magazines">magazines</a>—is often overshadowed by imports from the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-Vipond2011y_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vipond2011y-397">[395]</a></sup> As a result, the preservation of a distinctly Canadian culture is supported by federal government programs, laws, and institutions such as the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="Canadian Broadcasting Corporation">Canadian Broadcasting Corporation</a> (CBC), the <a href="/wiki/National_Film_Board_of_Canada" title="National Film Board of Canada">National Film Board of Canada</a> (NFB), and the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Radio-television_and_Telecommunications_Commission" title="Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission">Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission</a> (CRTC).<sup id="cite_ref-Edwardson2008c_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Edwardson2008c-398">[396]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Symbols">Symbols</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_Canada" title="National symbols of Canada">National symbols of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Beaver_sculpture,_Centre_Block.jpg" class="image"><img alt="The mother beaver sculpture outside the House of Commons" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg/220px-Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="198" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg/330px-Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg/440px-Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2298" data-file-height="2066"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Beaver_sculpture,_Centre_Block.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i>The mother beaver</i> on the Canadian parliament's <a href="/wiki/Peace_Tower" title="Peace Tower">Peace Tower</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[397]</a></sup> The five flowers on the shield each represent an ethnicity—<a href="/wiki/Tudor_rose" title="Tudor rose">Tudor rose</a>: <a href="/wiki/English_people" title="English people">English</a>; <a href="/wiki/Fleur_de_lis" class="mw-redirect" title="Fleur de lis">Fleur de lis</a>: <a href="/wiki/French_people" title="French people">French</a>; <a href="/wiki/Thistle" title="Thistle">thistle</a>: <a href="/wiki/Scottish_people" title="Scottish people">Scottish</a>; <a href="/wiki/Shamrock" title="Shamrock">shamrock</a>: <a href="/wiki/Irish_people" title="Irish people">Irish</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Leek" title="Leek">leek</a>: <a href="/wiki/Welsh_people" title="Welsh people">Welsh</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Canada's national symbols are influenced by natural, historical, and Indigenous sources. The use of the <a href="/wiki/Maple_leaf" title="Maple leaf">maple leaf</a> as a Canadian symbol dates to the early 18th century. The maple leaf is depicted on Canada's <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Canada" title="Flag of Canada">current</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Red_Ensign" title="Canadian Red Ensign">previous flags</a>, and on the <a href="/wiki/Arms_of_Canada" title="Arms of Canada">Arms of Canada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-symbol1_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-symbol1-400">[398]</a></sup> The Arms of Canada are closely modelled after the <a href="/wiki/Royal_coat_of_arms_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom">royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom</a> with French and distinctive Canadian elements replacing or added to those derived from the British version.<sup id="cite_ref-Gough2010g_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gough2010g-401">[399]</a></sup> Other prominent symbols include the national motto "<i lang="la" title="Latin-language text"><a href="/wiki/A_Mari_Usque_Ad_Mare" class="mw-redirect" title="A Mari Usque Ad Mare">A Mari Usque Ad Mare</a></i>" ("From Sea to Sea"),<sup id="cite_ref-Nischik2008_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nischik2008-402">[400]</a></sup> the sports of <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">ice hockey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lacrosse" title="Lacrosse">lacrosse</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Beaver" title="Beaver">beaver</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada_goose" title="Canada goose">Canada goose</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_loon" title="Common loon">common loon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canadian_horse" title="Canadian horse">Canadian horse</a>, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the Canadian Rockies,<sup id="cite_ref-symbol1_400-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-symbol1-400">[398]</a></sup> and more recently the <a href="/wiki/Totem_pole" title="Totem pole">totem pole</a> and <a href="/wiki/Inuksuk" title="Inuksuk">Inuksuk</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Nels_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nels-403">[401]</a></sup> Material items such as <a href="/wiki/Canadian_beer" class="mw-redirect" title="Canadian beer">Canadian beer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maple_syrup" title="Maple syrup">maple syrup</a>, <a href="/wiki/Knit_cap#Canadian_tuque" title="Knit cap">tuques</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canoes" class="mw-redirect" title="Canoes">canoes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nanaimo_bar" title="Nanaimo bar">nanaimo bars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Butter_tart" title="Butter tart">butter tarts</a> and the Quebec dish of <a href="/wiki/Poutine" title="Poutine">poutine</a> are defined as uniquely Canadian.<sup id="cite_ref-Nels_403-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nels-403">[401]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[402]</a></sup> Canadian coins feature many of these symbols: the loon on the <a href="/wiki/Loonie" title="Loonie">$1 coin</a>, the Arms of Canada on the <a href="/wiki/50-cent_piece_(Canadian_coin)" title="50-cent piece (Canadian coin)">50¢ piece</a>, the beaver on the <a href="/wiki/Nickel_(Canadian_coin)" title="Nickel (Canadian coin)">nickel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Berman2008_405-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Berman2008-405">[403]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Penny_(Canadian_coin)" title="Penny (Canadian coin)">penny</a>, removed from circulation in 2013, featured the maple leaf.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[404]</a></sup> The Queen's image appears on <a href="/wiki/Canadian_dollar" title="Canadian dollar">$20 bank notes</a>, and on the obverse of all current Canadian coins.<sup id="cite_ref-Berman2008_405-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Berman2008-405">[403]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Canadian_literature" title="Canadian literature">Canadian literature</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Canadian literature is often divided into French- and English-language literatures, which are rooted in the literary traditions of France and Britain, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[405]</a></sup> There are four major themes that can be found within historical Canadian literature; nature, frontier life, Canada's position within the world, all three of which tie into the <a href="/wiki/Garrison_mentality" title="Garrison mentality">garrison mentality</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[406]</a></sup> By the 1990s, Canadian literature was viewed as some of the world's best.<sup id="cite_ref-Dominic2010_409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dominic2010-409">[407]</a></sup> Canada's ethnic and cultural diversity are reflected in its literature, with many of its most prominent modern writers focusing on ethnic life.<sup id="cite_ref-Dominic2010_409-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dominic2010-409">[407]</a></sup> Arguably, the best-known living Canadian writer internationally (especially since the deaths of <a href="/wiki/Robertson_Davies" title="Robertson Davies">Robertson Davies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mordecai_Richler" title="Mordecai Richler">Mordecai Richler</a>) is <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Atwood" title="Margaret Atwood">Margaret Atwood</a>, a prolific novelist, poet, and literary critic.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[408]</a></sup> Numerous other <a href="/wiki/List_of_Canadian_writers" title="List of Canadian writers">Canadian authors</a> have accumulated international literary awards,<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[409]</a></sup> including <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Laureate</a> <a href="/wiki/Alice_Munro" title="Alice Munro">Alice Munro</a>, who has been called the best living writer of short stories in English;<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[410]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Booker_Prize" title="Booker Prize">Booker Prize</a> recipient <a href="/wiki/Michael_Ondaatje" title="Michael Ondaatje">Michael Ondaatje</a>, who is perhaps best known for the novel <i><a href="/wiki/The_English_Patient" title="The English Patient">The English Patient</a></i>, which was adapted as a <a href="/wiki/The_English_Patient_(film)" title="The English Patient (film)">film of the same name</a> that won the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Academy Award for Best Picture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[411]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Canadian_art" title="Canadian art">Canadian art</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_Jack_Pine,_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Oil on canvas painting of a tree dominating its rocky landscape during a sunset" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg/220px-The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="203" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg/330px-The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg/440px-The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1105"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_Jack_Pine,_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Jack_Pine" title="The Jack Pine">The Jack Pine</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Tom_Thomson" title="Tom Thomson">Tom Thomson</a>. Oil on canvas, 1916, in the collection of the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Canada" title="National Gallery of Canada">National Gallery of Canada</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Canadian visual art has been dominated by figures such as <a href="/wiki/Tom_Thomson" title="Tom Thomson">Tom Thomson</a> – the country's most famous painter – and by the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_Seven_(artists)" title="Group of Seven (artists)">Group of Seven</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[412]</a></sup> Thomson's career painting Canadian landscapes spanned a decade up to his death in 1917 at age 39.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[413]</a></sup> The Group of Seven were painters with a nationalistic and idealistic focus, who first exhibited their distinctive works in May 1920. Though referred to as having seven members, five artists—<a href="/wiki/Lawren_Harris" title="Lawren Harris">Lawren Harris</a>, <a href="/wiki/A._Y._Jackson" title="A. Y. Jackson">A. Y. Jackson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Lismer" title="Arthur Lismer">Arthur Lismer</a>, <a href="/wiki/J._E._H._MacDonald" title="J. E. H. MacDonald">J. E. H. MacDonald</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Varley" title="Frederick Varley">Frederick Varley</a>—were responsible for articulating the Group's ideas. They were joined briefly by <a href="/wiki/Frank_Johnston_(artist)" title="Frank Johnston (artist)">Frank Johnston</a>, and by commercial artist <a href="/wiki/Franklin_Carmichael" title="Franklin Carmichael">Franklin Carmichael</a>. <a href="/wiki/A._J._Casson" title="A. J. Casson">A. J. Casson</a> became part of the Group in 1926.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[414]</a></sup> Associated with the Group was another prominent Canadian artist, <a href="/wiki/Emily_Carr" title="Emily Carr">Emily Carr</a>, known for her landscapes and portrayals of the <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Pacific_Northwest_Coast" title="Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast">Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[415]</a></sup> Since the 1950s, works of <a href="/wiki/Inuit_art" title="Inuit art">Inuit art</a> have been given as gifts to foreign dignitaries by the Canadian government.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[416]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Canada" title="Music of Canada">Music of Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The Canadian music industry is the sixth-largest in the world producing internationally renowned <a href="/wiki/List_of_Canadian_composers" title="List of Canadian composers">composers</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Canadian_musicians" title="List of Canadian musicians">musicians</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_bands_from_Canada" title="List of bands from Canada">ensembles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-HullHutchison2011a_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HullHutchison2011a-419">[417]</a></sup> Music broadcasting in the country is regulated by the CRTC.<sup id="cite_ref-AchesonMaule2009_420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AchesonMaule2009-420">[418]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Academy_of_Recording_Arts_and_Sciences" title="Canadian Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences">Canadian Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences</a> presents Canada's music industry awards, the <a href="/wiki/Juno_Award" title="Juno Award">Juno Awards</a>, which were first awarded in 1970.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[419]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Music_Hall_of_Fame" title="Canadian Music Hall of Fame">Canadian Music Hall of Fame</a> established in 1976 honours Canadian musicians for their lifetime achievements.<sup id="cite_ref-Hoffmann2004_422-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hoffmann2004-422">[420]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anthems_and_nationalistic_songs_of_Canada" title="Anthems and nationalistic songs of Canada">Patriotic music in Canada</a> dates back over 200 years as a distinct category from British patriotism, preceding the Canadian Confederation by over 50 years. The earliest, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bold_Canadian" title="The Bold Canadian">The Bold Canadian</a></i>, was written in 1812.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[421]</a></sup> The national anthem of Canada, "<a href="/wiki/O_Canada" title="O Canada">O Canada</a>", was originally commissioned by the <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_governor_of_Quebec" class="mw-redirect" title="Lieutenant governor of Quebec">lieutenant governor of Quebec</a>, <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9odore_Robitaille" title="Théodore Robitaille">Théodore Robitaille</a>, for the 1880 <a href="/wiki/F%C3%AAte_nationale_du_Qu%C3%A9bec" class="mw-redirect" title="Fête nationale du Québec">St. Jean-Baptiste Day</a> ceremony, and was officially adopted in 1980.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[422]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Calixa_Lavall%C3%A9e" title="Calixa Lavallée">Calixa Lavallée</a> wrote the music, which was a setting of a patriotic poem composed by the poet and judge Sir <a href="/wiki/Adolphe-Basile_Routhier" title="Adolphe-Basile Routhier">Adolphe-Basile Routhier</a>. The text was originally only in French before it was adapted into English in 1906.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[423]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_Canada" title="Sports in Canada">Sports in Canada</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Hockey players and fans celebrating" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg/220px-Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg/330px-Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg/440px-Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1280"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Canada's <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">ice hockey</a> victory at the <a href="/wiki/2010_Winter_Olympics" title="2010 Winter Olympics">2010 Winter Olympics</a> in Vancouver
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/History_of_Canadian_sports" title="History of Canadian sports">roots of organized sports in Canada</a> date back to the 1770s,<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[424]</a></sup> culminating in the development and popularization of the major professional games of ice hockey, lacrosse, <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baseball" title="Baseball">baseball</a> and <a href="/wiki/Football" title="Football">football</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[425]</a></sup> Canada's official national sports are ice hockey and lacrosse.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[426]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">Golf</a>, soccer, baseball, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Skiing" title="Skiing">skiing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cycling" title="Cycling">cycling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swimming_(sport)" title="Swimming (sport)">swimming</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bowling" title="Bowling">bowling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canoeing" title="Canoeing">canoeing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Equestrianism" title="Equestrianism">equestrian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Squash_(sport)" title="Squash (sport)">squash</a> and the study of <a href="/wiki/Martial_arts" title="Martial arts">martial arts</a> are widely enjoyed at the youth and amateur levels.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[427]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada shares several <a href="/wiki/Major_professional_sports_leagues_in_the_United_States_and_Canada" title="Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada">major professional sports leagues</a> with the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-ButenkoGil-Lafuente2010_430-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ButenkoGil-Lafuente2010-430">[428]</a></sup> Canadian teams in these leagues include seven franchises in the <a href="/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">National Hockey League</a>, as well as three <a href="/wiki/Soccer_in_Canada#Major_League_Soccer" title="Soccer in Canada">Major League Soccer</a> teams and one team in each of <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">National Basketball Association</a>. Other popular professional sports in Canada include <a href="/wiki/Canadian_football" title="Canadian football">Canadian football</a>, which is played in the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Football_League" title="Canadian Football League">Canadian Football League</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Lacrosse_League" title="National Lacrosse League">National Lacrosse League</a> lacrosse, and <a href="/wiki/Curling" title="Curling">curling</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MorrowWamsley2016_431-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MorrowWamsley2016-431">[429]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Canada has participated in almost every <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a> since <a href="/wiki/Canada_at_the_1900_Summer_Olympics" title="Canada at the 1900 Summer Olympics">its Olympic debut in 1900</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-MallonHeijmans2011_432-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MallonHeijmans2011-432">[430]</a></sup> and has hosted several high-profile international sporting events, including the <a href="/wiki/1976_Summer_Olympics" title="1976 Summer Olympics">1976 Summer Olympics</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Howell2009_433-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howell2009-433">[431]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/1988_Winter_Olympics" title="1988 Winter Olympics">1988 Winter Olympics</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-HorneWhannel2016_434-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HorneWhannel2016-434">[432]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/1994_Basketball_World_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="1994 Basketball World Championship">1994 Basketball World Championship</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Blevins2012_435-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blevins2012-435">[433]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/2007_FIFA_U-20_World_Cup" title="2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup">2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ParentChappelet2015_436-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ParentChappelet2015-436">[434]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/2010_Winter_Olympics" title="2010 Winter Olympics">2010 Winter Olympics</a><sup id="cite_ref-Development2006_437-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Development2006-437">[435]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fromm2006_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fromm2006-438">[436]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/2015_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup" title="2015 FIFA Women's World Cup">2015 FIFA Women's World Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[437]</a></sup> Most recently, Canada staged the <a href="/wiki/2015_Pan_American_Games" title="2015 Pan American Games">2015 Pan American Games</a> and <a href="/wiki/2015_Parapan_American_Games" title="2015 Parapan American Games">2015 Parapan American Games</a>, the former being the largest sporting event hosted by the country.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[438]</a></sup> They are also scheduled to co-host the <a href="/wiki/2026_World_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="2026 World Cup">2026 World Cup</a>, alongside Mexico and the United States. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <div style="float:right;">
       <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Canada.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of Canada.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/32px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="16" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/48px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/64px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600"></a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Portal:Canada" title="Portal:Canada">Canada portal</a>
      </div>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-politics-155"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-politics_155-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Brokerage politics: A Canadian term for successful <a href="/wiki/Big_tent" title="Big tent">big tent parties</a> that embody a <a href="/wiki/Pluralism_(political_philosophy)" title="Pluralism (political philosophy)">pluralistic</a> catch-all approach to appeal to the median Canadian voter ... adopting centrist policies and <a href="/wiki/Electoral_alliance" title="Electoral alliance">electoral coalitions</a> to satisfy the short-term preferences of a majority of electors who are not located on the ideological fringe."<sup id="cite_ref-MarlandGiasson2012_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MarlandGiasson2012-152">[152]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CourtneySmith2010_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CourtneySmith2010-153">[153]</a></sup> "The traditional <i>brokerage</i> model of Canadian politics leaves little room for ideology" <sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Canadian-342"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Canadian_342-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">All citizens of Canada are classified as "Canadians" as defined by <a href="/wiki/Canadian_nationality_law" title="Canadian nationality law">Canada's nationality laws</a>. However, "Canadian" as an ethnic group has since 1996 been added to census questionnaires for possible ancestral origin or descent. "Canadian" was included as an example on the English questionnaire and "Canadien" as an example on the French questionnaire. "The majority of respondents to this selection are from the eastern part of the country that was first settled. Respondents generally are visibly European (Anglophones and Francophones), however no-longer self-identify with their ethnic ancestral origins. This response is attributed to a multitude or generational distance from ancestral lineage.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[339]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[340]</a></sup></span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

Retrieved <span class="nowrap">February 8,</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Population+size+and+growth+in+Canada%3A+Key+results+from+the+2016+Census&amp;rft.pub=Statistics+Canada&amp;rft.date=2017-02-08&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.statcan.gc.ca%2Fdaily-quotidien%2F170208%2Fdq170208a-eng.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACanada" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-IMFWEOCA-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEOCA_8-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEOCA_8-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEOCA_8-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IMFWEOCA_8-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/weo-database/2020/October/weo-report?c=156,&amp;s=NGDPD,PPPGDP,NGDPDPC,PPPPC,&amp;sy=2018&amp;ey=2025&amp;ssm=0&amp;scsm=1&amp;scc=0&amp;ssd=1&amp;ssc=0&amp;sic=0&amp;sort=country&amp;ds=.&amp;br=1">"World Economic Outlook Database"</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>. October 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">March 30,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=World+Economic+Outlook+Database&amp;rft.pub=International+Monetary+Fund&amp;rft.date=2020-10&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.imf.org%2Fen%2FPublications%2FWEO%2Fweo-database%2F2020%2FOctober%2Fweo-report%3Fc%3D156%2C%26s%3DNGDPD%2CPPPGDP%2CNGDPDPC%2CPPPPC%2C%26sy%3D2018%26ey%3D2025%26ssm%3D0%26scsm%3D1%26scc%3D0%26ssd%3D1%26ssc%3D0%26sic%3D0%26sort%3Dcountry%26ds%3D.%26br%3D1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACanada" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://data.oecd.org/chart/5OdN">"Income inequality"</a>. <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-UNHDR-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-UNHDR_10-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/hdr2020.pdf">"Human Development Report 2020"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Programme" title="United Nations Development Programme">United Nations Development Programme</a>. 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Canada" title="Government of Canada">Government of Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Standards_Council_of_Canada" title="Standards Council of Canada">Standards Council of Canada</a> prescribe <a href="/wiki/ISO_8601" title="ISO 8601">ISO 8601</a> as the country's official all-numeric date format: 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPublic_Works_and_Government_Services_Canada_Translation_Bureau1997" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Public_Services_and_Procurement_Canada" title="Public Services and Procurement Canada">Public Works and Government Services Canada Translation Bureau</a> (1997). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.btb.termiumplus.gc.ca/tcdnstyl-chap?lang=eng&amp;lettr=chapsect5&amp;info0=5.14">"5.14: Dates"</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/canadianstylegui0000unse/page/97"><i>The Canadian style: A guide to writing and editing</i></a> (Revised&nbsp;ed.). Dundurn Press. p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/canadianstylegui0000unse/page/97">97</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-55002-276-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-55002-276-6"><bdi>978-1-55002-276-6</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=5.14%3A+Dates&amp;rft.btitle=The+Canadian+style%3A+A+guide+to+writing+and+editing&amp;rft.pages=97&amp;rft.edition=Revised&amp;rft.pub=Dundurn+Press&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-55002-276-6&amp;rft.au=Public+Works+and+Government+Services+Canada+Translation+Bureau&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.btb.termiumplus.gc.ca%2Ftcdnstyl-chap%3Flang%3Deng%26lettr%3Dchapsect5%26info0%3D5.14&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACanada" class="Z3988"></span> The <abbr title="day">dd</abbr>/<abbr title="month">mm</abbr>/<abbr title="year">yy</abbr> and <abbr title="month">mm</abbr>/<abbr title="day">dd</abbr>/<abbr title="year">yy</abbr> formats also remain in common use; see <a href="/wiki/Date_and_time_notation_in_Canada" title="Date and time notation in Canada">Date and time notation in Canada</a>.</span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-38">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFTanner1999" class="citation web cs1">Tanner, Adrian (1999). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.heritage.nf.ca/aboriginal/innu_culture.html">"3.          <li id="cite_note-66"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-66">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHarris1987" class="citation book cs1">Harris, Richard Colebrook; et&nbsp;al.          <li id="cite_note-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-124">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/11-402-x/2012000/chap/geo/geo-eng.htm">"Geography"</a>.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://climate.weather.gc.ca/climate_normals/results_1981_2010_e.html?stnID=3002&amp;lang=e&amp;StationName=Regina&amp;SearchType=Contains&amp;stnNameSubmit=go&amp;dCode=1">"Regina International Airport"</a>. <i>Canadian Climate Normals 1981–2010</i>. <a href="/wiki/Environment_Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="Environment Canada">Environment Canada</a>.          <li id="cite_note-Brooks2004-156"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Brooks2004_156-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFStephen_Brooks2004" class="citation book cs1">Stephen Brooks (2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=DeQnPIXV5CEC"><i>Canadian Democracy: An Introduction</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-Smith2014-157"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Smith2014_157-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMiriam_Smith2014" class="citation book cs1">Miriam Smith (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=iG4rAwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA17"><i>Group Politics and Social Movements in Canada: Second Edition</i></a>. University of Toronto Press. p.&nbsp;17. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4426-0695-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4426-0695-1"><bdi>978-1-4426-0695-1</bdi></a>. <q>Canada's party system has long been described as a "brokerage system" in which the leading parties (Liberal and Conservative) follow strategies that appeal across major <a href="/wiki/Cleavage_(politics)" title="Cleavage (politics)">social cleavages</a> in an effort to defuse potential tensions.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Group+Politics+and+Social+Movements+in+Canada%3A+Second+Edition&amp;rft.pages=17&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Toronto+Press&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4426-0695-1&amp;rft.au=Miriam+Smith&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DiG4rAwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA17&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACanada" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Johnson2016c-158"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Johnson2016c_158-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDavid_Johnson2016" class="citation book cs1">David Johnson (2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=I_HzDQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA13"><i>Thinking Government: Public Administration and Politics in Canada, Fourth Edition</i></a>. University of Toronto Press. pp.&nbsp;13–23. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4426-3521-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4426-3521-0"><bdi>978-1-4426-3521-0</bdi></a>. <q>...most Canadian governments, especially at the federal level, have taken a moderate, centrist approach to decision making, seeking to balance growth, stability, and governmental efficiency and economy...</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Thinking+Government%3A+Public+Administration+and+Politics+in+Canada%2C+Fourth+Edition&amp;rft.pages=13-23&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Toronto+Press&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4426-3521-0&amp;rft.au=David+Johnson&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DI_HzDQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA13&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACanada" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-171"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-171">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-216"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-216">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFinkel1997" class="citation book cs1">Finkel, Alvin (1997). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/ourlivescanadaaf0000fink/page/105"><i>Our Lives: Canada after 1945</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-OECDBLI-244"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-OECDBLI_244-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBrown2002" class="citation book cs1">Brown, Charles E (2002). <i>World Energy Resources</i>.          <li id="cite_note-274"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-274">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBolton1972" class="citation journal cs1">Bolton, C. T. (1972).
